Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ III Complete is an absolute masterpiece
Still the best Civilization game ever made.

[h3]Quick Notes[/h3]

‚Ä¢ The best Civ of the entire series. Every Civ after has departed from this, which is a real shame. I would've loved to see some quality of life updates and a remaster. Still an easy recommendation.
‚Ä¢ The gamestudio mentioned wanting Civ to feel more like a board game. Civ 4 doesn't accomplish this, Civ 5 does so a little bit, Civ 6 absolutely does, but it's to its detriment. The uncomplicated nature of this PC game, that gets as hard as you like, makes it an absolute masterpiece.
‚Ä¢ Be prepared to play for hours on end, there's no such thing as a short game in Civ 3. You'll be saying: "One more turn" as the sun goes down, only to see the sun come up, feel tired all day, and do it again the next night.

Without doubt my favourite installment within the Civilization franchise. The fact that almost a decade after it still sucks me in like the first day is a testament to its ever lasting appeal. You only know when you start a game but you never know when you'll put it down or finish it; it's just so addictive unlike Civ V which has no lasting appeal. For me Civ 3 felt like digital chess. It's a game that has you continually thinking what your next moves will be and rewards handsomely forward-thinking and carefully planning ahead. I even like the graphics which are not as cartoonish as Civ IV. Along with Brian Reynold's Alpha Centauri, Civ 3 is my all-time favourite game. The amounts of hours I've poured into it can be tallied by the thousands. If you like 4X TBS games you owe it to yourself to play this classic. The Conquests expansion infused new life by way of historic scenarios which are fleshed out very nicely. Special mention goes to Rise of Rome and the Napoleon scenario where you relive the glory and bloodshed of the lost Empires. Civ IV has overshadowed its predecessor significantly but Civ 3 will always have a place in my heart and harddrive and I return to it at least twice a year.

I have been playing this game for 20 years.   I still play it today.   Its probably the best of the Civ series.  You can still stack units.  This can lead to absolutely epic battles.   In my last game the computer was coming out with stacks of dozen or more infantry and my artillery and bombs slowly whittled them down.

It's ability to simulate WW1'esque long grinding wars were units are lost by the several dozens every turn makes it truly unique.  It's really something to watch a massive empire slowly fall apart over decades due to war fatigue, conscription, and artillery and bombers slowly pounding away at its infrastructure.

When they got rid of the ability to stack units the game went downhill.

Civ III.

Who hasn't played or at least heard of Civ III? It's a beautifully elegant, turn-based, world building game. Build your civilization up through the millennia - research and battle your way to world domination.

"Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ III Complete" is a comprehensive package that includes the original "Civilization III" game along with its expansions, "Play the World" and "Conquests." Developed by Firaxis Games and published by 2K Games, this edition was released to offer the definitive experience of one of the most influential turn-based strategy games. Set against the backdrop of human history, players lead a civilization from the dawn of time to the space age, striving to achieve one of several victory conditions through exploration, diplomacy, cultural advancement, and warfare. 

Gameplay Mechanics
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"Civilization III Complete" refines the series' formula, offering deep and engaging gameplay that balances empire management, strategic warfare, and diplomatic negotiations. Players must carefully manage their cities, resources, and population while exploring the world and interacting with rival civilizations. The game introduces unique features such as culture, which can influence borders and city loyalty, and more complex trade and diplomacy systems, adding layers of strategy not seen in its predecessors.

Strategic Depth
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
The strategic depth of "Civilization III Complete" is immense, with a variety of paths to victory and countless strategies to explore. Each civilization offers unique advantages, encouraging players to adapt their tactics based on their chosen nation and the evolving geopolitical landscape. The inclusion of the "Play the World" and "Conquests" expansions further enriches the game's depth, introducing new civilizations, scenarios, and features that challenge even veteran players.

Graphical and Audio Presentation
Rating: 7/10 - Good
For its time, "Civilization III Complete" featured detailed graphics that brought the world map, units, and city improvements to life. While the visuals may appear dated by today's standards, they retain a certain charm and clarity that contribute to the game's immersive experience. The audio, including the soundtrack and sound effects, effectively complements the gameplay, though it is relatively minimalistic compared to more recent entries in the series.

Replayability
Rating: 10/10 - Masterpiece
The replayability of "Civilization III Complete" is outstanding, with virtually endless possibilities for different game experiences. The random map generation, diverse civilizations, and multiple victory conditions ensure that no two playthroughs are the same. The additional content from the expansions, along with the game's modding support, further extends its longevity, making it a title that players can return to time and again.

Overall Entertainment Value
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
"Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ III Complete" offers exceptional entertainment value, combining strategic depth, engaging gameplay, and extensive content into a package that appeals to both strategy enthusiasts and casual gamers alike. Its balance of accessibility for newcomers and complexity for seasoned players makes it a standout title in the strategy genre.

Overall Summary and Score
Overall Rating: 8.8/10 - Excellent
"Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ III Complete" is a seminal title in the turn-based strategy genre, offering a rich and expansive gaming experience that has influenced countless subsequent games. Its combination of strategic gameplay, replayability, and the depth of content in the complete edition cements its status as a classic.

Highly Recommended for fans of strategy games and those interested in historical simulation and empire-building, especially of those who love Civ2. It stands as a testament to the enduring appeal of the series' formula, combining deep gameplay mechanics with the grand scope of human history, offering a timeless challenge to strategists and empire builders.

Teaboy's Basic(ish) Reviews....I read a lot of reviews when looking at games on Steam, and it quickly gets tiring ‚Äì those who write involved, down to the micron scale reviews, although helpful, end up like looking at War & Peace when you‚Äôve only got time for a quick 5 minute dump!  This is middle of the road and to the point ‚Äì not easy for me as I tend towards sesquipedalian loquaciousness!  Vociferously Verbose?  Alright, verbal diarrhoea.  (Although I hate panning a developer‚Äôs work and all the time, effort and love they put into designing these ‚Äì it is their life after all ‚Äì this is my honest, personal opinion of my level of enjoyment.  Sorry devs!).  

A note on time played:  My Steam clock does not seem to work properly, indeed, it even minuses time on occasion!  Plus, I have a tendency to wander off and leave games running at times, so time played may not be entirely accurate!  


Teaboy‚Äôs Tonsil Titillators or Toenail Titbits!  (Rating)  

Tonsil Tickler (Totally Tops):  The frenchy of which you always dreamt!  To quote a master, ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs got a tongue like an electric eel and she likes the taste of a Man‚Äôs tonsils!‚Äù.  An absolute masterpiece and joy to play.  

The Tits (Terrific):  Everyone loves playing with these!  Not THE best bit, but such fun on their own you can be lost for hours....mmmm.  What most games you really like score ‚Äì perfection is so rare after all.   

Torso Teaser (Taker of your Time):  It‚Äôs a flat stomach....sure it‚Äôs nice to look at, run your fingers over, slobber on a bit, sometimes that bellybutton gets your motor running....but it's just basically the corridor between the two ‚Äògaming rooms‚Äô.  The definitive ‚ÄòMeh‚Äô - the middle ‚Äòsideways thumb‚Äô option for which everyone on Steam cries.  

Todger/Tadger & (scroTum) Taters (Tedious):  Is it an ‚Äòa‚Äô or is it an ‚Äòo‚Äô?  Who cares!  The meat can be fun to play with for about 5 minutes of your entire day, the rest it just hangs there and generally gets in the way of doing something else.  The main problem of course, is the two veg sticking to your inside thigh.  This is what this game feels like ‚Äì the occasional/rare bouts of fun, the rest bobbing like a 19th century British Policeman (now you know why!).  

Toenail Tornado (Total Toss):  A playthrough so appalling it‚Äôs like being trapped in a Turkish sauna with the ugliest, hairiest, fattest, sweatiest beast of a neolithic hominid who‚Äôs trimming his toenails using pliers and the splinters are reminiscent of a scene from the Normandy Landings.  My god how did this get released!?  


Teaboy Touts (Score):  Torso Teaser/The Tits


The Review:  

None of my overused exclamation marks for the score for this one, but you can have one here!  Reason being,the sheer frustration factor of RNGesus.  

Now this is a tricky one, a Really tricky one.  On the one hand, Civ was the first 4x game I ever played on the good old Commodore Amiga back in the early 90s, and BOY did I fricking Love the turd out of it!  But oddly, having currently played Civ 1, 2, 3 and 4 + BtS with 5 in library, I actually prefer 1!  Nowt beats the original, eh?  

1 had it all, and although the world is never big enough for my liking in any of the iterations of the game, 1 was just perfection.  2 was literally a carbon copy with Alpha Centauri tacked on the end as a 2nd world to play concurrently with  the 1st (Earth, obvs), but there was no civilopaedia so you had no idea what anything did and you were starting from scratch again with a single settler - I could never get anything going and quickly grew tired of it.  

Now we get to 3.  The last in the line before they changed what everything did in 4 - I hated this!  As in your city improvements effects all changed in 4.  So 3 is good for keeping the old style with a few changes, mostly extra stuff, but I noticed they got rid of supermarkets!  So a limit on your growth!  They also nerfed transport capacity - like Transport from 8 to 6, and Carriers from 8 to sodding well 4!?  Booo!  

However, these are just annoyances.  By far the worst is the literally offensive rng.  This has two parts also:  The fact that I always used to play on the easiest setting simply because I always wanted the longest game I could and the higher the level the sooner the game ended - however, even with the new facility to turn off ALL victory conditions, it Still ended in 2050 with a warning in 2030 that you had 20 years left....so just wrap up your civilization please, vacuum the floors and lock the doors on your way out of existence - wtf!?  

Anywhos....I decided to play on just the 3rdsetting.  Out of what....9, 10, a dozen?  I forget.  But that's besides the point, the point being that it was still on the 'piss easy' side of things.  AND YET....I started to pay particular attention to combat results.  It was glaring in its conclusion.  Seriously, 80% of Equal battles with identical units would end in a loss for my side regardless of attack or defence or terrain bonuses.  Even my F*&^ing Battleships would regularly be beaten by F!"¬£ing Cruisers, Destroyers ffs and Even SUBMARINES who suck!!  The latter only being good for their ability to target a specific ship - kill Transports!  And once enemy has Stealth Bombers your cities are fkd.  I had the missile defence improvement, 4 Jet Figthers and SIXTEEN missile units in 1 city and they killed 1/10.  They destroy everything but missile, factory, aqueduct and hospitals.  Kills all but 1 citizen.  All ships and planes and defending units last.  Wtf is the point.  Whereas my Stealth Bombers miss almost 50%.  

Sorry for the rant.  The 2nd part being the oddity of how the rng worked on a turn basis.  Very strange.  I saved and repeated certain movements.  Once the save slot is reloaded, the result was ALWAYS the same, yet different from original play.  I actually had an enemy unit next to my base which I attacked with about 6 units that ALL died, EVERY $&(¬£W*& TIME!!  I changed simply the square from which I attacked and hey presto, I killed it.  This is just F&^%ing warped.  

I wanted to finish this game before writing, but I was dealt a totally turd hand from the offset - I used archipelago so each nation would have its own land.  I got the second smallest island with a quarter of it at the south pole so all tundra and almost NO resources at all!  Literally I got Iron and Spices.  That was it!  No Saltpetre, no Coal, no Oil, no Rubber.  Come late game, without Oil/Rubber you are pretty much screwed.  (Note:  You have Settlers and Workers in this third iteration of Civ instead of Settlers who eventually evolved into Engineers and did everything.  You can now no longer change every square into whatever terrain you wish - tundra is useless and cannot be altered, also mountains cannot be settled and if you settle on a resource it does not provide the benefit, all cities give the same 2 food 1 shield with only the trade changing) 

Now, randomly new deposits appear, and some disappear - just as I build a city amongst another empire to try and get a deposit!  Unbelievable!  So way after Coal had passed its use, a deposit appeared on my land!  At least I could build railways.  I did get Uranium and Aluminium which are end stage game Resources.  However, they give very little benefit compared to Oil and Rubber.  E.G.  You are stuck with Riflemen whilst everyone else is not only beyond Infantry but building Mech Inf, or I've got TOW Inf compared to their Modern Battletank.  Coupled with the rng, I got massacred every time.  I could only build Nuclear Submarines and thankfully eventually Aegis Cruisers whilst the computer players are knocking out Battleship after Battleship (ironically they seem to prefer Aegis when they get them).  I actually got Oil just as I was trying to settle next to a deposit, again in enemy territory.  Again, unbelievable.  Or not, it seems.  But I never got Rubber.

I love that you can utilize the terrain tactically, and even strategically. The static defenses can tunnel the enemy into prepared killing zones.
I like how the ancient warfare differs from the medieval and modern warfare.
On the other hand, the diplomacy is well developed as well. You can maintain good relationships, for a while ...

Of course the city management is the backbone. The annoying part is that the corruption is hardly explained. You get big troubles with it, if you have many cities. Try to read about Optimal City Number (OCN)!

This will be an update to my original comprehensive review of this game, as before I will split the review for newcomers to Civilization III (Civ 3) and those that have played both played modern civilization games to this point. Hopefully this serves as a clearer introduction and review of this game I have loved since my teenage years. 

For Newcomers, I would not recommend this as a first civilization game to get into for the following reasons that should be noted. This game has some complications for some to play the game, most can be resolved with a bit of file management, but most remaining and introduced bugs (mainly sound bugs) must be self-remediated and through self-experience some can be painful, i.e.  ‚ÄúThe Diplomacy Menu Sound bug‚Äù.  However, if you have the know-how or willingness to learn, there are helpful guides and threads on both Steam and CivFanatics to resolve these issues. 

Additionally, for newcomers to both Civ 3 and 4X games in general, Civ 3 is rudimentary in its design, but at its time served as a novel concept. Civilization III was the first Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization game published outside their MicroProse days. It brought graphic and visual design innovations including more emphasis on their 2.5D graphic sprites while keeping with an isometric layout. That being said, the graphics in vanilla setups have not ‚ÄúStood the Test of Time‚Äù, but as with many things, this game maintains a faithful modding community with thousands of available content additions provided freely to the community. 

For all its faults, it does keep to its promise, it is a fully complete game, which in this modern gaming scene, a complete game can be a refreshing breath. And it is a game that you can get into fast, with a descriptive Civlopedia that can teach you core fundamentals of the game, however no tutorial exists for this game. It can be a game that can be easy to learn for strategy game-lovers but will provide a challenge all the way into the higher difficulties, though at the expense of AI just being given powerful bonuses as the difference between difficulties. 

Now onto the review for those coming from other Civ games and other 4X games. Should you get this game, keep the following things in mind. The games UI can be un-intuitive for some, most of it is done through right-clicking on cities and units to interact with their drop-down menus that pop up. However, there are plenty of hot-keys available for units‚Äô available actions. This game solely favors ‚ÄúWide-Builds‚Äù and so you will always be incentivized to continue expanding and producing vast quantities of units, which can be a drag in the endgame when micro-management becomes exhausting at times. 

Game speed is something that can‚Äôt be altered within the game and instead is dependent on scenario-based games. And once the basics are learned and you are proficient with the game, a single player game can be played out completely within a few hours. It really has served as one of those plug-n-play strategy games, and for a 4x game, is still exemplary in that role. 

I mentioned micro-management, this game is pretty neat in the sense it feels extremely city based. Happiness and discontent are based on population solely and is dealt with on a per-city basis. Additionally, science and gold production are one and the same, with a national budget slider controlling your science and treasury growth, as well as, money spent on your citizen‚Äôs happiness, while culture is often based on the physical development of your cities. With such a simple rule-set, games are straightforward and feel extremely grounded. 

The last thing I want to high-light but was mentioned repeatedly already. This game has an extensive modding community, and while it may not be as active, it maintains a large archive of files, use at your own risk, but many overhauls and noteworthy mods have installation guides and more. Finally, this game has many files found in the file browser, just right-click the game on steam to access those files. Play the World and the original Civ 3 (no-dlc) can be found, each of these with their scenario and rules editors. Modding is extremely easy for this game (barring overhauls) and the guides are really amazing, big shout-out. I have made my own unpublished modifications myself, with little background in modding previously. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

So is this review a little too wordy and you need that zoomer brevity, no worries I break down the pros and cons here as bullets.
Pros:
-	The game is straightforward, with player guides and an in-game encyclopedia of rules, concepts clear and concise. 
-	A Potato could run this game, but if you take the modding route, RAM and CPU power will be your friend. Late Game Lag is also a phenomenon found in this game. 
-	Combat Units are very clear, and fill classic niches in games, Offensive, Defensive, Maneuver, Ranged and Siege Units, with Aerial Units being added much later with rules similar to Siege Units. 
-	Science, Culture and Gold Production is straightforward with majority city-based empire management. 
-	Wonderful CivFanatics Community and Modding Community, as well as Steam Guides

Cons:
-	Combat is outdated, with most Units fighting until their own destruction or the enemy unit‚Äôs. Additionally, based on simple dice-like combat, so expect the classic Civ 4 Catapult kills Tank scenario on rare occasion. 
-	Diplomacy is easily exploitable, especially for the AI to cheat together and gang up on you, namely through alliances and Tech Trading. 
-	Difficulty scales based on AI cheats and bonuses.
-	It‚Äôs an old game, bugs arise, and the graphics aren‚Äôt the prettiest. Additionally, it used to be very difficult to get the game to start on Windows 7 and 8.1. Issues minimized with Windows 10, but no experience with Windows 11 installation of the game.
Note: Many of the Cons can be minimized by altering values in scenario/rules editors available in the game files or larger community. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
This final section is for Multiplayer and personal history with the game. Multiplayer is not something I am familiar with any expertise. To my understanding, it exists and still has old veterans of the game. Multiplayer guides and strategies exist and are probably your best bet to getting into Multiplayer. I believe, Steam allows you to play MP directly nowadays, or it‚Äôs hosted through GameRanger (though this was back in 2018/2019). I have been playing this game since 2010 or so (on physical copies of the game), it became my introduction to the Civilization series and separately 4X games outside the old retro Warlords III/IV games. Now in my late twenties, this game still serves as one of my fonder memories and game I find myself returning to. Whether you get it on sale or you pay its already cheap price, it's completely worth it in my eyes! 

Feel free to comment on this review if you have other questions about this game!

I don't know if you CAN continue to run your civilization after a victory, because the 2 times I did get an endgame and went to click "OK", my game immediately freezes and stops working, making me have to quit the game.

Civ 3 was my favorite of all the Civilization series. I used to play it for hours at a sitting via CD back when first released.  Had I received exactly the same as I used to have on CD, I'd be very happy, despite the year 2000 graphics.

Unfortunately, the Steam version, though it says "complete" is not.  It lacks the editor which made the game such fun for me, trying out different scenarios of my creation.  It also struggles to start or work well on my Windows 10 Pro.  I'm never sure when the game will hang, and it often does around the Fireaxis screen when just booting up or after entering the new game conditions.  

I suppose it may be possible, if one was willing to take the time and effort, to install a Windows 2000 emulator and get Steam to work with it somehow, that the game might run smoothly.  You'd still be missing the editor, which kind of negates the title "Complete".

Still playable and enjoyable after so many years. The mechanics are simple yet effective.
AI is [b]ruthless[b/], even in lower difficulties. It will send waves of units in an intelligent way, rather than just crashing and dying against a strong city they will pillage and seek weaker targets and gradually eat away at your territory. You will be the subject of joint declarations of war. You will be nuked. Sometimes multiple times. And just when you think you are winning, within 20 turns you will be on the edge of losing.

It makes the AI in later Civs (looking at you especially, #6!) seem like it's designed for infants. How they can get it right in 3 yet wrong in 6 really beats me.

Of course, there are some annoyances. The 'death stack' of endless AI units piling down on your cities and running unchecked through territory is irritating, and time consuming to deal with. To get ahead, you really need to micro-manage pops in cities. Pollution pops up too frequently and too early, being another micro-managed tedium. The wonders are bland, and are hard to get even on mid-difficulties. Even the wonder movies in 2 made them meaningful whereas in this it's just 'meh'. There's only one great person, a general, which you need to create armies, and you can win a ton of battles yet still be without one throughout the entire game. Golden ages might happen once or never. 

But that AI makes it a real challenge, and little things like the palace and city views are what they should have kept in later versions.
Single Player is okay, but they broke the LAN capabilities and the Audio is completely gone.

To get this game running in your desktop resolution. Find conquests.ini in the conquests folder (*\steamapps\common\Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete\Conquests)
and add:
keepres=1

If you require a custom resolution, also without potentially changing your desktop resolution with the above ini line.
Use this:
https://www.bcheck.net/apps/reso.htm
I recommend 1600x900 for 16:9 on a 24 inch monitor. The city menu will be 4:3 regardless, but I don't mind. There are custom menus and stuff over at civfanatics.com

This game's music can glitch out, stuck in a loop, and with no music for leader negotiations.
Here's a fix:
https://www.indirectsound.com/
Extract the two files into the conquests folder.

Source:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_psi0Lxoh2E

Lastly, a quality of life mod for beeing able to browse leaders in negotiations (similar to the newer games), better unit stack management, fix for AI to use artillery and much more:
https://forums.civfanatics.com/resources/c3x.28759/

:D

I played this game years ago, and even though I did have some fun playing this game again, I cannot recommend it. It runs very poorly on modern computers, and is filled with audio and graphical glitches. The game also has problems of crashing to the desktop. It often crashes during the introduction cutscene, and crashes much of the time when you finish a game (and doesn't record the victory or score). Even discounting these game-breaking glitches, the gameplay has not held up after all of these years.

The classic Civilization game that has truly stood the test of time is Civilization IV. Get that game instead of this one. Or if you want a 2D classic experience similar to Civilization II / III, but more refined, then play Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri. You can buy that one on GOG. It has an excellent story and compelling premise, and many features in that game are implemented in Civlization IV. 

TL;DR: Play Civilization IV or Alpha Centauri.

For me, this is the original - the OG of PC strategy games. I know Civ2 was big before this but this game took the fundamentals of what made Civ a fun series of games and turned them up to 11. I could wax poetically on the impact this game had on my life but it's interesting how a game made 20+ years ago still has game mechanics that could be considered timeless. I still think that Civ5 is the best game of the Civ series, but this game is a close second which is insane considering how old it is. Game mechanics aside, this game also has one of the most underrated soundtracks of any game from any era. For a few bucks, you can experience PC gaming history and if you're anything like me, a nice stroll down nostalgia lane is included.
It's a gamification of history.

If you ever liked any strategy game, this game is a must have... I played, probably, more than 15 000 hours and still going strong. There is no better entertainment  value, for money, out there. I would pay not 5 bucks, that I payed, for this game, but 1000$, if I had to...  It is the best, Civilization game, in the series, by far, as Civ 4, has been destroyed, by nonsense such as artillery, "trowing" itself, onto the opponent to do damage, no lethal bombardment for planes and few other things. The only three things, that Civ 4 has, is health in the cities (making a game richer), "live" in-game editor (must have, for this kind, of long games), and great peoples concept. But Civ 3 Complete, has the most comprehensive editor, of any game, I ever played. That is why I was able to play, for 20 years, and still be entertained. I created 200 additional units, from strategic bombers, to static bunker defences, and I found an Icon, for each, on Civ 3 Fanatics, web site. So. now I have everything, from hummer, to Suhoi Su 35, as part of the game, that works (there is a web link, on Civ fanatics site, that explains how to do this). I also created a scenarios: from my infantry scenarios, where you can build modern infantry units, even from ancient start to the game, to my modern scenarios, where AI starts with bunkers, over all of his strategic resources. Also you would think that bombing (modern me, all others ancient start), the ancient enemies would get old, but trust me it is great fun, with locked alliance option, you can have 31 enemies and fight them, all at once...Note: If you want to use editor, you need to find it first, in the Civ 3, directory and then use help menu to teach you what is what. It is the best help menu I encountered anywhere (not just gaming) , but still far from perfect. Anyway enough said, buy a game and play on easier level, as playing, Sid difficulty, without the editor, is not much fun. AI gets 3 settlers (to your one) and advances 2.5 times faster than you, in technological age. I played a game now-days, without editor and with all my knowledge of the game, all AI had tanks, while I had swordsman's. But, with editor, I created games, in which only I can build, all the Wonders of the World. Lol. It is about having fun, not adhering to, Mr Data's, sense of justice. It is all about abundance and only then, realism - only when it is fun to do so...I also deleted coal, from the game, in order to delete, railroads as they are, too unrealistic, with its infinite movement, on those railroads. So, game, with just roads, is way more entertaining and realistic, at the same time. But, even without editor, Civ 3 is so much better, than Civ 5 or six, and I have never completed, either Civ 5 or 6, but played, Civ 3 instead, even though I own all three games. In Civ 5 and 6, they destroyed the game, by not allowing to place, more than one unit, per hex. I spent more time, trying to place units, on the map, than playing the actual game, overall. Civ 4, on the other hand, I played, 1 to 50, compared to, Civ 3. That tells you all you need to know about this franchise...Civ 3: graphics, concept and editor, is the best, in the series, so you can not go wrong. There is some issues with interface, as it is poorly done, in a sense, that automatic unit activation, is all over the place, and it makes game harder to play. Also AI, does not use artillery, armies or sea invasions properly, but every game's AI is still like that, even now-days, and if you are looking for perfect computer game - you end up playing none...Enough said - have fun, anyway, and good luck....

As someone who has played quite a bit of Civ IV, V, and VI, this game is a whole different animal than the newer ones. It's relatively simple, there arent many menus and UI elements so if youre coming from the newer games itll feel like youre missing a lot of information. Mechanically there isn't a ton of depth either, the focus is on expanding like crazy and then micromanaging your population and finances and everything more intently vs the more specialized mechanics and strategies of the newer games. It makes each game and all of your cities feel pretty generalized and the game itself have a lot less character to be honest. All in all it seems much more like a scaled-up, turn based version of Age of Empires than what I'm used to from Civ at this point. Its also extremely long, research is way slower and you stay in each era much longer than the other games as well, which isn't inherently a bad thing if you like longer games anyway (I usually play epic speed in the other games so it doesn't really bother me). Edit: I'm realizing that there are less "eras" in the game than in its sequels, eg. the ancient and classical era are merged, medieval and renaissance are merged, etc. so each age is much longer but there are fewer of them so it probably balances out.

I will give it a thumbs up, I didnt entirely dislike it though it doesnt scratch the same itch. I do especially like the atmosphere of the game, the visuals and music are pretty interesting. I'll probably come back to it at some point when I feel I want something to fill that niche. And considering its very cheap I would say its worth picking it up and trying it regardless. I do recommend looking up a guide for your first game if youre coming from the newer games like me, the flow of the game is just so different and a lot of concepts dont translate over as much as you would think.
I liked the ability to actually build a modern civilization.
It's been a long time since playing the original on my Amiga. It's nice to spend some time in an early version of Sid's legend, where "just one more turn" can keep you up all night long.

As old as time itself and about as archaic in its crude simplicity. Anyone picking up a 22 year old game in this day and age either has a fondness for unrefined and quite clunky game or a heavy dose of the memberberries.. However in the case of old Civilisation games the graphics have truly not altered that much of the core gameplay that will be very familiar to enjoyers of the later Civ-titles. Personally I picked this title up to game through the ‚ÄúMiddle-earth: Lord of the Mods‚Äù pack that truly transformed the generic Gandhi vs Attila gameplay into a more mellow fantasyesque theme where you can shoulder the mantle of Theoden, KING! in an all out struggle for domination against the forces of darkness.. 

The base game is fine and has aged quite well, however there are alot of players reporting issues with compatibility and getting it to play smoothly. This is the pure bane of retrogaming these days and though I had no problems with my arguably ok-ish rig your mileage may vary. If you truly enjoy the other civ-titles this is more of the same, and if you, like me, was there 3000 years ago, bashing in barbarian skulls and taking names, you might find a strange familiar feeling when booting up this relic of a bygone past. 

I recommend it, but I assume I'm already preaching to the choir.. Who in their right mind would pick up a 22-year old Civ title on a whim? Well, in that case, good on you kind fellow, we will make a deity out of you yet!

One of my favorite games of all time. I have fantastic memories of playing this for hours and hours as a little kid, rediscovering it in my early teens trying to force my friends to play it with me, and finally sitting in college lectures plotting world domination from my laptop instead of taking notes.It's clunky compared to the later games in some ways and not exactly balanced (you can stack units, cities have no protections without units in them, and you can decrease happiness for a few turns to get unholy amounts of money during golden ages). Overall though, this is still what I regard as the most streamlined and refined Civilization to this day. The art style is pleasing without having any extra glam, the soundtrack is ridiculously good, and the UI makes a lot of sense once you come to grips with it. This version also contains the content from the Conquests expansion pack which adds a ton of additional Civs, units, scenarios, and online play. Certainly worth $5. None of the games since have grabbed me quite as much as this one, and it was here that I first learned the power of "one more turn".

Sid Meier's Civilization III: Complete is just simply an amazing game. It goes through history, allowing players to simulate being a world leader in the past. Personally, I really like exploring the map and completing the tech tree, but players can become whatever they want in the game, whether that is a mad scientist like me or a warmonger. While the game is old, it plays very well. The animations are great, and it even includes multiplayer. Overall, it's a great game that you'll play for hours on end without realizing it.

This is my absolute favourite Civilization game, I have played it for years (I own all of the mainline Civ games, and a few "offshoots"), and it still runs with few issues on my Windows 10 machine. It is easily moddable, great new concepts added, and I have played countless hours of it.

+ Comfy 2.5D graphics
+ Charming things lost in later games: create-your-own palace, city view, and leaders' outfits changing through the ages (Genghis Khan in a suit!)
+ First in series to introduce culture, cultural victories
+ First in series to introduce unique civ traits
+ Happiness is city-by-city instead of global
+ Challenging combat; beating AI at Prince is harder than Civ V Immortal

- This game is REALLY hard. If you normally play Warlord/Prince on Civ 5/6, you will not even survive the ancient era. 200 hours in I can only beat Emperor (normal)
- Combat can get tedious because of unit stacking, late game is a nightmare
- Building "tall" is not possible. You will get steamrolled if you have 4 cities to the AI's 32
- UI is just "OK" but if you've played Civ you'll get it

Anecdotal, but I had almost zero problem getting this running on Windows 10/11.
I've played CIV III over many years, with the "just one more turn" effect stronger than ever.

Over 20 years later and this is still a fantastic game. An overhead strategy game that allows for a surprising amount of creativity, variation in play and replay value. The world editor that comes alongside it is an amazing addition that makes it very difficult to get tired of. 

Whether you want to sit in one little spot and grind til your wrists break, expand outward and conquer the map, try a unique challenge, or utterly decimate every last rival until you're the last one left on the map, this game gives you a huge amount of customization both in gamestyle and winning conditions. It's also fantastic how after so long this game still has multiplayer support, meaning even friends across the world can wage war with each other, whether you want to do it turn based or simultaneously.

I do dock a few tiny points for how slow multiplayer loading can be, but given it's such an old game and only the third installment in a huge franchise with multiple spinoffs and is grinding up toward its 7th mainline title, I can fully understand how and why the internet and LAN options are not entirely optimized.

Especially considering that nowadays this game is only 5$ for the complete package including all the DLC originally released, I HIGHLY recommend this one to anyone who likes strategy games. Sure, the later games have better graphics, different strategies and may add some features that make this one fairly outdated in comparison, it's still an absolute blast to play and worth giving a shot if you haven't already, or coming back to if you've been ignoring it for awhile.

I have played this game ever since it came out. In total, I should have clocked around 4000-5000 hours on Civ 3 Vanilla, Play theWorld and Conquest. This game is very satisfying. I can allow myself to share the following about Civilization 3: Complete edition:

1) You can allow yourself to play with mouse only. This is not only very convenient but it is also a testimony for an almost perfect GUI.

2) Well arranged icons, buttons and menus. Everything is exactly where you expect it to be.

3) This version, the complete edition is the best you can have. Each civilization in this game feels unique and each special unit feels special. With Conquest and this Complete edition, they finally managed to find the balance.

They finally managed to fix the issue with the Great Person: it really provides +20% Scientific Output. Although, you might want or need to spend it on a Wonder?! You never know, as no two games are the same.

Always play in such a way, that you use the specific bonus for your civilization. When your special unit wins in battle, you will have a Golden Age! Never forget about that. If you are a peaceful builder, then build wonders, which triggers Golden Ages for your specific type of civilization.

Stack all "Double Scientific Output" wonders in one city.

Always try to produce an Army, which to be victorious. Then, you can build more armies and after the Pentagon, you can have 4 units per Army. After you produced the maximum amount of Armies, you can disband the oldest ones (with older obsolete units) and build a brand new one, full with the latest and deadliest units.

Do not go for dead-end research (Steam Engine, Fascism, etc.), especially if you have a small scientific lead, so that you can gain an even bigger margin. Never underestimate the power of the carrier! Always try to get Philosophy first (one free Technology), then the Great Library and then Republic. If you meanwhile manage to get some resources and roads, plus save yourself from conflicts, then you will win later in the game. If not, then Monarchy/Feudalism is the right way, especially if you will not have any luxury resources. In such scenarios, you can skip researching Republic, as there is Democracy down the line. Also, if you do not have luxury resources and nobody to trade with, then Sistine Chapel is a must.

I might one day write a "how-to play civ" manual for all civ games with the most optimum strategies for each game, according to the amount of resources, the terrain you are on and the neighboring civs around you, as per turn 10 or 15. Remember, every turn counts and sometimes games are being lost for 1-2 turns.

Never-ever underestimate Espionage! Never!

So I am a poor old man and I cannot afford a nice computer right now. Life. I can play CIV III on my little weenie hp laptop. I have CIV VI, and played it a great deal, but CIV III it is until I get a computer with the guts to run it. What I have found is this: the older versions are far more combat oriented. I suspected as much, as religion became more important in later versions, as did diplomacy, with the addition of city-states. The simplicity of the earlier versions lends to conquest victories, as cultural and diplomatic victories offer little in regards to actual gameplay. These victory types seem much more passive in CIV III. But I love this version, because the AI is brutal and unforgiving. You cannot make mistakes, you always pay. I believe that makes these versions a tad more realistic in feel, though low reward visually.

When i first played Sid Meier¬¥s Civilization I was almost 10 years old. And yes, it was the first part. I didn¬¥t had my own PC and played with my friend Benjamin on his father¬¥s Computer. I was so excited about the game that I told everyone from the 4000 BC timeline until about 2000 AD. The cities and nations, which you could expand at will, were such a nice game concept that when I wasn¬¥t sitting in front of the computer with Bejamin, I would spend hours in my children¬¥s room imagining how our civilization might be progressing.

The second part of Civilization was published almost 5 years later. In the meantime I had my own PC. So I already played the second part extensively and had partly built up such large nations that the rounds seemed endless to me. I still remember a score with Russia on the real map; it was one of my greatest saves in Civilization II.

Sid Meier¬¥s Civilization III was published in 2001. When i heard about it, I immediately ran to the computer store near my parents¬¥house. I begged my parents until they agreed to buy me a new PC. So, i ran back to the computer store and bought a new PC for Civilization III.

And I have to say it was the best Civilization of all time up to that point. The intro was cinematic at the time and the animated units enthralled me so much I thought I was in Sid Meier heaven. The expansion of the palace is also still present in this part, wich was taken over from the first part.

Okay, you could see this text as a clumsy advertisement for Sid Meier¬¥s Civilization series. But in truth, only the little boy is speaking here, who sat down in front of the game Civilization a long time ago and has been a real Sid Meier fan ever since.
This by far the best of all Civilization series. The level of control you have over your civilization is vast and vastly reduced in the sequels.

I have played this game since I was 8 back before there was a Conquest DLC let alone a complete edition and it still my favorite of any of the Civ titles. It doesn't have the polish, expanded features or animations of VI but  it definitely has the feel of those fantastic early 2000's games that can't be replicated nowadays. That quirky charm is huge here and unlike some of the other nostalgic games of the time, this doesn't have nearly the same difficulty curve. If you set it to a higher difficulty the AI will definitely make quick work of you but lower ones make it enjoyable to discover or get your bearings after not playing it for 20ish years. Overall: Civ 3 is one of the classics that brought me into civilization series. I have probably hundreds of hours in this game if we include my disc playtime. This game has a lot of depth that may not be noticed at a first glance. Coupled with the dlc you'll have a civ 4 experience for the most part. Game graphics are pretty old but fitting for a 2001 game. The music is nostalgic and inspiring/relaxing. There are plenty of mods and maps on the forums still being made today. This game has steep difficulty spike as the Ai cheat in a a lot of ways and have no problem landing musketmen on your shores while you're still learning how to make walls in your cities. The combat is very rng heavy allowing for the infamous spearman beating a tank situation to happen. Get this game if you're looking to play a cheap civilization that still holds it's weight. You won't be disappointed.
Took me about twenty years to master the "monarch" difficulty setting. I hope for twenty more years of fun.
Classic Civ gameplay

[b]‚äï[/b]this game received a much-needed update to get rid of the nonfunctioning Gamespy multiplayer! What a relief! This is my favorite installment of the Civ series. The game has a slew of nice preferences to choose from, even including an aid for the colorblind. More of a board game feel as opposed to strategy. STELLAR soundtrack.

[b]‚äñ[/b]New to the game? Go into the options and turn the tutorial on. It‚Äôs off by default for some reason. The cutscenes look horrible because of age and stretching. Resolutions are ROUGH. Compared to modern installments, the opponent civs act rather erratically, to the point of being nonsensical. There is no balancing, so some Civs are OP and others you would ideally never play.

[b]‚úé[/b]It's easy to lose track of time in Civ3. It's great fun and I think it hits a goldilocks zone of being more succinctly-designed than 4 or 5 but more appealing than 1 and 2. If you don‚Äôt have nostalgia for it though, it might just be the game you know and love but with less features.

Before talking about the game in itself, I want to say thank you to Sid Meier about the franchise. At the beginning a video game adaptation of the Civilization board game, it began to be a universe of its own. I've played every single games from Sid Meier the first being Civilization III. this game defined my entire personality and made me discover at the age of four countless cultures and heroes. I'm glad to have grown with Civilization III and Age of Empires II. 

This game is in my opinion the best of the franchise. I don't care about graphics when the gameplay and overall design is of this quality. When I was a kid I've played this game for hundred of hours without being bored and I didn't have the complete edition at that time. The excitement of finding the original game on steam (my cd is too old for windows 10 and 11) with double the number of civs that I remembered plus scenarios plus the original map editor... It was too much. If like me you grow with this game, you can understand the overall joy of finding this masterpiece.

The gameplay is fantastic, as good as I remembered. You have unique game mechanics that no other Civ games retried. It is a shame and at the same time makes it rare gem. To name a few of theses unique mechs: the palace, the best diplomacy system of all civ Games, custom civilization principle, easy city management...

if you like graphics with big flashing screens and Uncanny Valley Nightmares you will find this game outdated and boring. Civ III does not give instant gratification. It also has a comedic tone with the leader portraits that are changing in each era. Civ VI may have been inspired by the goofy and well tought designs of some characters from Civ III, while Civ V is more serious.

On the multiplayer level, I can't say much.  I never were a multiplayer guy for Strategy games. But I intend to do it soon. I did some games with my brother and AI but not full players. However the multiplayer screen is well optimized.

However I've found some disturbing bugs and compatibility problems in this version that can break the entire experience. For instance, you will never hear the diplomacy sound of leaders because of the two channel trouble. Also when you finish a game and click on the X button, the game will freeze. You must click on Esc. This is ruining the game in some ways but some awesome individuals found the solution to these bugs.

To conclude: If you enjoy good gameplay over graphics, this game is for you. The game was well put into modern computers and i wish the same thing could be done to Civ I and Civ II that were also fun to play.

I am willing to admit that I may be completely nostalgia blinded by this game. It was the first Civ game I played, the first 4X game I played, and quite possibly the first strategy game I played. I loved it then and I still love it now.

My review is only going to be geared towards people who have played other Civilization games, since I think the odds of coming across Civ3 before the others is really low.

This game does not have the variety of effective playstyles that other games offer. However, the balance of thr game and the quality of the scenarios is as good as it gets.

Running an effective empire is far more micro-management intensive than in any other installment in the series. Resources like food and production are not stockpiled in cities, so they will have to have their yields carefully observed to be as efficient as possible. You also have to deal with and manage corruption draining away at your resources. This extra skillset is not completely necessary, however, unless you want to tackle the higher difficulty levels (Demigod+).

Additionally, there is less of a focus on diplomacy than you may be used to in later Civilization games. A lot of the disposition modifers are not explained in-game properly and you will need the wiki.

The highlight of this game is in the warfare and military-industrial complex. Being able to field and fund an effective army while simultaneously growing your empire tall and wide is the most important aspect of Civilization 3. Units stack on top of each other, so controlling chokepoints and defensive positions is far more effective. There are other nuances, but this is just an example.

Overall, I think this game is definitely worth buying if you enjoyed any other Civilization game. It is especially recommended if you enjoyed the turn-based combat of other games.

As a bonus if you read this far, I‚Äôve ranked the scenarios in order of which are the most fun to play (or replay over and over, like I have):

1. Middles Ages ‚Äî well-balanced scenario with new units and technologies
2. Rise of Rome ‚Äî elongated version of ancient era, with a heavy focus on military and expansion instead of building tall
3. Sengoku - Sword of the Shogun ‚Äî new tech tree and resources, fresh take on the game after you‚Äôve gotten bored of vanilla
4. Napoleonic Wars ‚Äî simulates regular game industrial warfare well
5. Wonders of the Ancient World ‚Äî Extended ‚Äúancient‚Äù era, but fun map
6. Age of Discovery ‚Äî Fun concept, but very short scenario
7. Mesoamerica ‚Äî Extended ‚Äúancient‚Äù tech tree
8. Fall of Rome ‚Äî Pay attention to the Elimination ruleset
9. WWII in the Pacific ‚Äî It‚Äôs actually terrible. I don‚Äôt recommend playing it at all unless you are a completionist

A review from me to me

Decided to revisit civ 3 for one game after more than a decade.

Due to tech trading the AI will constantly breathe down your neck. They will have modern armies capable of waging war in the later eras.
Techs are also consistently used as bargaining chips in war declarations and peace talks.
The AI is acting irrational sometimes declaring suicidal wars when they have nothing to gain (except maybe raze an unprotected city deep within your borders).
Mutual protection pacts are very weird as they can be signed while you are at war, and will only trigger when your are attacked within your own borders.
You can pay other AI to join one of your wars (20 turn military alliance), and if you don't your opponents just might. You cannot bribe your opponents into wars you don't take part in, nor can you negotiate peace treaties for other civilizations.
There are no denouncements, friend declarations or economic alliances but you can at least sign trade embargoes.

Units are fairly cheap and expendable. They have to fight to the death unless they are able to retreat. You need a few dozen units to successfully wage a war. This leads to the game devolving to a few stacks of doom, as there is no 1 unit per tile limitation. An unchecked AI might attack you with hundreds of units while pushing dozens more per turn. Bombardment units are very strong when amassed. Airplanes can even kill units. Units need transports to travel across the sea. All units cost 1 commerce per turn, unless they are captured (workers, siege) so you are encouraged to maintain a modern military.

Slavery is weak for rushing projects (offering only 20 production per citizen sacrifice and lowering the city happiness for 20 turns). But it can be used as a tool for ethnic cleansing.
There is no production overflow (meaning you need to optimize the number of production a city is making to avoid wasting turns). There is also no research overflow, meaning you need to lower the slider before completing a tech.
The land grab by the AI in the early game is insane, and you need about 20 cities to prosper (too many cities to manage for my taste).
You can swap production at any time to any project, which means all wonders will disappear in rapid succession as the AI just swaps to the next available wonder. You can also prebuild with an expensive building before unlocking a new wonder. Chopping woods does not add production to a wonder.

The citizen ethnicity system is great (each citizen maintains their ethnicity on the map as free captured workers and inside cities where they will protest against war on their motherland. There is a small chance citizens are assimilated each turn based on your government. In the later game you can draft your population into conscript combat troops, but only your own nationals.

Cities need aqueducts and hospitals to grow past specific population limits (6, 12).
Infrastructure is very strong usually offering 50% yield bonuses.
Luxuries are very strong and fun to collect.
Since happiness is local and the settler cost does not scale up the only limiting factor to your expansion is higher and higher corruption.

The governments are fairly distinct and interesting. Revolution duration on the other hand is random and unfun (you lose 2 to 8 turns) if you're not religious.
Despotism debuff is awkward to work with as only a few resources are capable of providing more than 2 food. Republic and Democracy extra commerce bonus is not clearly described.
Your capital's location is crucial for your empire's productivity and corruption makes distant colonies almost unworkable. But at least it can be moved if you can afford the production.

Land is boring as there's only grassland, plains, desert, tundra, hills and mountains. Only flatland is able to support features like forests, jungles and marshes. They serve no purpose other than being removed (forests provide a measly 10 production, allow no improvements and protect somewhat against desertification)
Mountains are passable so it is harder to create choke points. The square grid also doesn't help. You need to make barricades in your border towns so that the AI cannot attack them in 1 turn. 
Improvements are boring, there are only mines and irrigation. Resources need only a road to be connected.
Roads are your empire's financial backbone due to their 1 commerce yield (especially under a Republic or Democracy). This means all land will have roads and railroads, making the landscape very ugly.
The land map is made out of squares which makes movement inferior to hexes.
Cities can only reach 2 tiles away from the city center (they can work at most 20 tiles), meaning there is rarely a reason to go over 20 population.
Late game you can fine tune the exact population number of a city based on its surrounding land (by turning irrigations to mines, training workers or drafting).
Since workers are so cheap you can force grow a new city by feeding workers into it.

Other than luxuries, strategic resources, techs and diplomatic agreements there isn't much to trade.
Espionage is somewhat useful. There is no religion.

Only one unit is required to capture/raze a city. (if undefended)
Units can freely trespass through your land opening you up to ugly sneak attacks. You can ask them to pull out but they might declare war (without being evicted from your lands).
You get a small return of production when you disband units in a city, making it possible to funnel production into it.
Re basing airplanes has unlimited range (OP). You can also re base nukes to submarines.
Armies pillage for free and can attack multiple times in a turn (OP).
Air bombing is realistic. You either damage/kill units, destroy city buildings, kill population or miss.

With the huge number of units in a war, it can get very tedious to control, especially since the game will annoyingly keep jumping between 'random' units. I get war weariness as fast as my population.
Pollution clean-up is annoying since you need to reassign the citizen to the tile.

The game is less complex than 4, 5 or 6. But still has an interesting charm and some unique features.

[i]Disclaimer: I own this on both Steam and GOG and play it only on GOG now, but I figured I should post a review here as well, since it's such a great game.[/i]

The 4X strategy genre can be a bit overwhelming and difficult to get into (though not as tough as grand strategy) but there are a couple games that have solid tutorials and less of a steep learning curve. Endless Space 2 and Stellaris come to mind at first, but...

... I'd be remiss to not talk about just how fantastic Civilization 3 is. Widely considered to be the greatest in the series, and one of the greatest 4X games of all time, Civ 3 is a brilliant example of why this genre is so fun. The progression design of the Civ series matches perfectly with the gameplay of the genre, allowing the player to begin at the start of a civilization and build their empire up through constant progression. That progression, however, is entirely up to the player. Want to be diplomatic and avoid wars? You can build your empire to do that. Prefer to just stomp on your enemies and conquer the world? Again, you can build your empire to do that. Want to isolate yourself for scientific progression or build a civilization upon trade? Those are also options.

In Civ 3, you never feel like you're being overwhelmed by a million gameplay systems but at the same time, you also never feel like you're being limited. In general, 4X is basically a sandbox take on turn-based strategy gaming and if you know me, you know I like my sandbox games. You may have heard that the Civilization games have always had that "one more turn" sort of gameplay and they are not joking. Every time I start up this game, I end up spending WAY more time than I planned to because it becomes addictive: you always want to take one more turn toward building your armies, or wonders of the world or progressing toward the next scientific unlock. You're always progressing to your goals.

I wouldn't say it's my absolute favorite 4X strategy game; that would be Stellaris. However, it is a landmark game that any strategy gamer should at least check out at some point. For that price point, really can't go wrong!

This is still my overall favorite civilization game. I've purchased and played Civ4 and Civ5, and they are good games, but they sacrifice strategy for tactics IMO. An annoyance to me, too, has always been that they no longer allow you to occupy mountains with with your forces, and it makes me want to yell at the developers, "Hello! Switzerland? Afghanistan?" The new games are flashier, more tactical, less strategic. That's my opinion. Civ3 is the deeply complex, tile-based, strategy game that I have been coming back to for years and years, even after playing full games of Civ4 and Civ5. Additionally, it is an OCD gripe of mine, I realize, but let me know when they get rid of the absurdity that your units can't fortify mountain positions. That's when I'm buying an new civilization game again. ;)

In the last week, this game has pissed me off SO FREAKING MUCH.

Let me back up.

When I was a kid, I'd wake up every morning around 6am and play this before school. I was a kid, I played the lower difficulties and over a few years worked up to harder difficulties. I remember having trouble with the higher difficulties...it seemed like no matter what I did there was no way to keep up with how fast all the AIs expanded and they were highly aggressive.

I've found this to be the case. I normally play civ 5 and 6 on the 2nd or 3rd hardest difficulty and can reliably win. On this one, good luck. The AI seems to start off with a significant headstart on number of cities. Doing my best to build settlers and staff them with spearman, I could get a sizeable empire but could not keep up overall. I learned that I needed to keep my gold low or else the AI would bully me into taking my gold. If I ever refused to give them gold or techs, they would declare war on me. I've yet to win a war, even after a few pretty good attempts (barracks in the capital, pumping out swordsmen or horsemen, depending on what I had available). 

I'm beyond frustrated so I'm walking away from this for a long while, but if I had to write some thoughts on what is required to win at higher difficulties...
1. Succumb to their threats, never go to war. If possible, give any money that you have to the AI so you gain their favor, rather than wait for them to bully you for it.
2. Expand as far as you can, then build walls along the outskirts. Make sure you have 1-3 barracks pumping out good units.
3. Build up a supply of 3 catapults, and whatever your unit of choice is (preference for swordsman or medieval inf) and deal a decisive blow before they knew what hit them. Once you attack of them, be ready for every AI to declare war on you.
4. Strike a hard enough blow at 1 AI to be able to overwhelm them, and that may give you enough momentum to encourage the other AIs to declare peace, then let you push past them in tech. This strat does work in later civ games. If it works here, you'll have enough cities to gain a tech lead, and discourage the other AIs from bullying you, until you're ready to steamroll past them in the 3rd era or so.

Civilization III is my favourite of the series. It was the first to add culture, and the civilization borders associated with the amount of culture you gathered. (Although Alpha Centauri, another Firaxis game, already used borders before.) it also added strategic and happiness resources to the game. Additionally units are now supported by gold instead of production. The scenarios are OK, but the real lasting game play is to be found in the random maps.

The various civillizations in the game are now more distinct as they now all have a unique unit, and a unique set of civilization traits. This does impact game play as each civilization now has each own best way to be played. But all the civilizations are still flexible enough that you can play any way you want too, and it is possible to win the game with any one of them. 

The main reason I enjoyed this version above any of the others is that the maps the game generates feel much more natural compared to any of the other games, Civilization II had the strange snake continents, while the maps in IV and V felt much smaller.

As a great tip, it is always wise to lower difficulty level; turn "always peace" on, and "no barbarians." This creates a much simpler path completing all of the timelines technologies, and completing them all without worrying of the annihilation of your republic. I could only imagine how great of an outcome if following the technology timeline was followed, installing each new technology learned physically into a rulers city-states, as these technologies are learned in turn. Like ceramics, and pottery leading to Granary for food production as an example; or an Aqueduct as a prerequisite for Plantation which produces sugar as another. There would be such great results. Whats great about the game is you can always launch another campaign, increase the difficulty to say Warlord or Emperor, turn to war back on, and do your best to overthrow rival nations.

A bit buggy, but definitely worth it. If you're having issues during startup, just exit and open it again (in severe cases, may need to restart computer). If game freezes between turns, don't touch anything or you'll crash it (it's just making moves for the AI and takes a bit when the game gets complicated towards the end). I'd also recommend saving one turn before the mandatory retirement year since the last page of the victory/defeat screen will often crash the game when you exit it. If you have the option of getting the physical disk instead of downloading on Steam, I recommend doing so as it's a bit less buggy, but if you can't get the disk, Steam is probably the best place to download. Hope this is helpful :)

The world, once a peaceful place; full of culture, cultivation, scientific advancements, and marvels of engineering. But like all good things, this Utopia did not last.
The world is scorched and scarred from a war of unprovoked diplomatic strain and hostility. The air now hardly safe to breathe.
It is the year 500AD. The Roman Legion sends the first Martian colonists by shuttle to preserve their way of life before Earth is destroyed by total atomic annihilation at the hands of the villainous mastermind Gandhi.

[i]Civilization III[/i] seems to have been the first game in the series to get a divided reception, the common denominator of which is friction between its strategy and simulation components. The most controversial feature appears to be the strategic resource mechanic, which is argued to give geography a lopsided tactical significance. It‚Äôs a reasonable thing to complain about, but it also happens to be historically and sociologically accurate. Similarly, the use of rigidly-defined eras prevents nonsensical arrangements like developing cars before developing the wheel. Personally, I‚Äôm a fan of anything that shakes players out of complacency, especially in this genre where fans tend to gravitate to a couple of optimal strategies. The other additions brought by [i]Civ III[/i] are more putatively worthwhile, including air missions, bombardment, and especially culture, which allows a faction to expand its borders and overtake cities via overwhelming media presence.

More than just adding new features, [i]Civ III[/i] also removes some annoying old ones like universal zones of control and generally cleans up the gameplay of its predecessors with better mouse support and more direct access to the in-game encyclopedia. The pacing and micromanagement are still weak links, as they drag matches out long after their outcomes have been decided, but that‚Äôs arguably inherent to the formula. The aesthetics, on the other hand, would be problematic in any genre. The music is terrific, and the visuals are more appealing than before, but they still utterly fail to cleanly display the gameplay information they‚Äôre expected to. Meanwhile, the sound effects range from acceptable, to annoying, to just plain odd. Nevertheless, this is my favourite of the first three [i]Civ[/i] titles. The [i]Complete[/i] version is appropriately titled, too, as it combines the content of the two expansion packs with multiplayer that actually works.

[b]Score: 8/10[/b]

I'm 22. About to be 23 in a few months. Here's my story.

When I was 14, I got struck down with depression. This led to me missing a lot of school in highschool and ultimately finishing 9th grade with a single credit.

I spent the rest of my teens trying to play catch up, finally receiving my high school diploma by age 19.

But when things seemed to be going well at 19, I was attacked and nearly raped. By the same relative who molested me my entire childhood. I became suicidal and was diagnosed with PTSD a year later.

At age 20, my mom died from cancer. She was a single parent and raised me all on her own since my deadbeat father left when I was 1.

I was now suffering from daily flashbacks due to my disorder.
Grieving the loss of the only parent I ever had.
And sobbing regularly thanks to the horrific things my father said to me while my mom lay dying in her hospital bed.

At 21, I dropped out of university.
I spent the rest of that year taking odd jobs at factories to pay my bills.

When I turned 22, I thought for sure it was my time to shine and begin living my life...

And then COVID happened.

I turn 23 on Dec 11.

I know I didn't waste my early 20s since I was suffering from so much traumatic shit in the span of a few years that others experience over a lifetime, some never at all.

But as I begin my 23rd year. I feel lost.
My PTSD has been in remission for over a year. And I've healed from the loss of my mother... but I'm struggling to shake the feeling that I lost so much time, and will always play catch up with others in the same life arena.

I don't really know why I wrote all this down, but I guess if there's any other lonely soul out there who happens to see my comment, I just want you to know that you got this.

We didn't choose our life circumstances.
We didn't ask for our lives to go off plan.

But we are alive
We're healthy
We've been blessed with another day

If you're the same age as me, our lives are only just beginning.
If you're older, you too can realize your dreams, escape the rigid safety found in your daily routine, and live the life you thought could never be possible.

If you still got a pulse, God still has a purpose.

If you're still hurting, talk to someone about it.

If you feel bored, get lost in a good book.

If you feel lost or confused, reconnect with that inner child and find time to spend doing the things you loved so much as a little one.

I hope to revisit this review in a few years, perhaps before my 20s are up so I can update how my life has gone since then. Til then...

What makes Civ3 stand the test of time? Combat. The only Civ that can compare to Civ3 in terms of combat is Civ4. Every Civ after 4 wants you to play with a handful of cities and no army. Civ3 is literally about taking over the world with massive armies of 500+ units. Even 4 reigned this in because in 4 you need siege units to take cities. The unit sound effects in Civ4 don't sound like battle hardened bad asses like they do in Civ3. Civ3 is not a perfect game but it is solidly designed game, built by solid PC game designers, prior to the corporatization of video gaming. 

The later Civ's don't improve on the flaws on the previous versions, they are completely different games with new flaws, and in my opinion they do not provide a good experience for military conquest of the world, while Civ3 perfectly encapsulates this.

I chose Civilization III as my first Civilization game because I wanted to see how the series evolved over the time. As a newcomer, take my review with a grain of salt since there may be some concepts I did not fully comprehend.

Civilization III had big ups and downs. It‚Äôs an aesthetically beautiful time sink and similar to Heroes of Might and Magic and X-COM (although mechanically I would say Civilization is more similar to Settlers), it hypnotizes you every time you play it. You lose concept of real life and time and end up playing for several hours non-stop. I‚Äôve had the feeling it plays very much like a board game and I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if Civilization series were heavily influenced by them.

There is no real campaign. You decide the rules (map, weather, victory conditions etc.) and start your custom game which can easily take dozens of hours. There are many civilizations to choose from but they are diverse enough to offer unique gameplay. You start in ancient times, build cities, research technologies, conquer other civilizations. 

There are some aspects I did not really like though. Firstly, some early strategies have too much influence on your fate. Don‚Äôt build enough cities or invest enough in technology, you may find yourself in an unwinnable state. AI obviously cheats in harder difficulties so you‚Äôll have to play in specific strategies in order to win rather than a flexibility on strategies. Diplomacy is pretty much broken and the AI never accepts your fair proposals, making the entire game mechanic obsolete. Corruption may sound like an interesting idea but in the case of Civilization III, it does more harm than good. Also, in mid to late game, you end up micromanaging hundreds of units and one turn can take quite a long time. I think it would be fair to say a game in Civilization III takes way too long with plenty of downtime. 

I would say Civilization III aroused my interest to the series and I will definitely be playing other titles. On the other hand, I can‚Äôt ignore its flaws and I‚Äôm pretty confident I won‚Äôt return to Civilization III specifically. 

[b]8/10[/b]

So I have always slightly jokingly called Civ 3 the best civ game of all time. Jokingly. Like we all knew 4 was the real fan favourite, right?

WRONG. 

I kid you not, playing any Civ game that isn't 3 just makes me wish I was playing 3. And that's not nostalgia talking! 
Happiness? 3 handled it best. Diplomatic Victory? 3 handled it best. Governments? 3 handled them best. Combat? Troops not getting levels helps to keep things Macro, and instead troops can increase their helthbar. Soundtrack? 3s is best. Religion? Doesn't exist - religious buildings only give Culture / Happiness. That is something about subsequent games that I did like. 

Civ 3 does have one weakness, and it's pretty glaring. Group bombard. The various shortcuts for controlling large stacks works great, right up until you're using bombard units. And that can get    t e d i o u s.

...I guess the moral of the story is that I no longer joke when I say Civ 3 is the best Civ game to date.

Seriously hard version of Civ! Like music, I think if you played this when younger you need to come back. Younger players will probably avoid the dated graphics and miss the challenge.  

I bought this when it came out, tried it, and got side-tracked by life and Civ IV, which I assumed must be better. Bought it again, cheap, on Steam and just got back into it, and WOW! This is a much tougher game than any other Civ I have yet played. How tough? I have been playing different Civs since Civ I was new. I am used to usually trying to maximize my cities, population, etc., and running up my score. Just to get a viable civ, I had to set AI aggression to the lowest level, even while playing at the lowly "Warlord" level. And I am still behind in several areas. Even at such a low level, enemies seek any weak cities to attack, establish cities in any open space in your continent, and are generally aggressive. Even Gandhi is psychotic! 

OK, what about the game? Lots of changes. One is the increased role of random luck. Now certain resources are needed to build units and wonders, even after you discover the tech. No Iron mines in your land? So much for swordsmen, legions, tanks, etc. No horses? No cavalry, chariots, etc. No saltpeter? No firearm units at all (including naval.) Get lucky and have Ivory early? You can build the Statue of Zeus and generate super-cavalry centuries before your enemies have anything close. To get resources you can now build "colonies" away from cities. The diplomacy is unforgiving. Also, strategic resources only emerge when you can use them, again if you are lucky. So cut-down your jungles and marshes and your chances of oil and rubber go way down! Also, barbarians re-spawn if you leave any territory undeveloped. 

Each civilization also gets its own special units. Ancient civs get them early, like Aztecs, Incas, and Hittites. Modern ones have to wait for Panzers and F-15s (by which time they may not be around or have the needed resources. Characteristics also determine starting tech and advantages in science, exploration, industry, etc. So picking your starting civ is no longer just a beauty contest. 

Downsides too: Graphics are 19 years old and not much improved on Civ 2 (some versions were better.) City view and wonder animations are pretty dull, as is your palace. Automation is terrible. AI workers always want to build mines not irrigated farmland. So you need to be very hands-on in city management, etc. And, as mentioned, the AI is really almost way too hard. This game is NOT for the casual player who just wants to build a nice civilization and a Hall of Fame score. Even lowest difficulty settings feel 'impossible.' There is an actual 'Impossible" level which is then superseded by the "Sid" level. I doubt I will ever make it to that one. I am not even sure Sid can win at that level! 

Since playing through, I have discovered a serious flaw, at least for me. When I reached the end, only once did the somewhat lame victory screen process. Since then I cannot get to a final screen, HoF, etc. Must lower my rating. This seems be a an issue with this version as it did not happen with CD-ROM. 

Bottom-line: $5 (or less on sale) buys you a whole lot of game for your money with hours of gameplay and even frustration. This is not for the casual gamer, but don't let the age and graphics fool you. This is a great challenge for hardcore 4X gamers! Don't be fooled that 4-6 must be harder than 3. This game makes Civ 4 look easy!
