Civ 3 is the foundation of all future titles in the series, and just as good as when it first released. All the bugs from previous titles have been worked out, and it is a solid game with a great replay factor. The additional civilizations available in the Complete edition only enhances that. Diplomacy and combat are nuanced without being complex, and there are plenty of ways to plan your cities depending on your priorities. 

All told, a good solid game despite its age, with enough depth and subtlety to keep it interesting for the veteran player while remaining simple enough that the rookie will not feel overwhelmed.

Civ III might be the best version of the entire Civilization franchise. It was the first version that introduced so many of the features that just made sense to me, like resources being necessary to build things. I loved Civilization 1 and 2, but it always irked me to see Viking War Elephants, especially when the Vikings were coming from nowhere near elephant territory. The introduction of strategic resources was a double edged sword, I have often lamented the computer placing my civilization with a unique unit that requires horses in an area completely devoid of horses for instance, but overall their addition to the game has made a more realistic simulation. Late game fights for coal or oil just make sense. Now on to the bad parts - the graphics are dated, it's just a reality of playing older games. It's not as bad as a lot of older games, but it is a noticeable thing. It is also kind of a pain to play on a newer system. Higher resolutions make the entire interface too small to read, lower resolutions do weird things to the rest of my system. Widescreen monitor support is basically non-existent. I get it, why put a lot of effort into an older version of the game? That said, I'd probably pay close to full price for a remastered edition of this version of Civilization. I played this for thousands of hours back in the day, and I would not have upgraded to Civilization 4 if my wife hadn't bought it for me for my birthday.  Civilization 3 also lacks a few features from newer iterations of the franchise. I am cool with it's lack of religion mechanics, I thought I'd want them, and I enjoy them in Civ 5 (Civ 4's implementation was poorly done), but keeping things more generalized seems to make for a better play experience, unless holy wars are really your favorite thing. Civilization 3 is probably the best in the franchise.

If you're looking for a classic turn-based strategy game then look no further. Firstly it's important to state that playing CIV III is a major time investment. Games will go anywhere from 35 Minutes to 16 Hours depending on the settings (Mainly Map Size/Difficulty.) To this day I have not been able to complete a game on Regent difficulty, so if you've got AI level IQ then this game could be a breeze. Playing on Settler difficulty however will allow you to calmly coast through your game and provide you with many avenues for victory and immersion. Although CIV III mods are hard to find due to the old forums going down, you can still find some of them. Couldn't recommend this game enough, it has a special place in my heart.

Oldness aside, i'd say this is the best entry in the Civ series.

I have played Civ II, III, IV, and VI. III is my favorite.

Here's some of the reasons why:

- The graphics/visual display are just so clear, everything is so easy to see. It can feel like a lot is going on on the map, but this art style makes it really easy to take it all in.
- While I always felt this base game did lack things like religion, civics, and city-states, I never felt it was implemented so well in the other games that they rise above Civ III.
- Although you can manipulate the pacing of the game, the actual pacing of the game-play always felt great to me. Things like world size, how far troops move, how long it takes to start a war, conquer an enemy, grab a new resource, etc. 
- The soundtrack hits the themes of your scientific age really well. Whenever I was in the modern age, I really felt like my civilization had culturally & emotionally matured, and knew their place in the world. I felt the soundtracks reflected this journey.
- Wide range of civilizations, unit choices, wonders, structures, etc. Without feeling overwhelming.
- The AI are actually pretty challenging. On max difficulty, almost no one has beat the game, especially without trying "cheap" tricks. But, that actually makes it really fun for role-playing as a less powerful nation, trying to hang on to its identity throughout time without being wiped off the planet, or technologically backward. It's almost like they bundled "The Sims" for cities/civilizations into this game too!

The mod support for Civ III can really extend its shelf-life too. I have sparingly played the multiplayer, I was able to be perfectly satisfied with just the singleplayer. Like all Civ games, it may have a slight learning curve, but you can jump in and start having fun playing immediately. The learning curve is more about how you might play really well against harder AI. Finally, note that this game is not heavily about combat, or visuals relating to combat. They exist, but the excitement of something like a large tank-battle in Red Alert 2 would not be present in this game. It's more about calculated, strategic decisions and movements, similar to a board game.

This game is obviously more simplistic than the later entries in the series, but that gives it a bit of charm in my opinion. My take on this game is that there is more going on on the board due to unit stacking and free tile enhancements (including roads and railroads), and less going on in the background due to lack of religion and civics trees. I personally like this game more than later entries in the series, but that may be due to nostalgia since I probably put 1000ish hours into the game on disk.

Fair warning for anyone thinking of jumping into this, the downsides compared to later entries are more micromanagement (cities will straight up shut down if there are enough unhappy people in them and you need to fix that on a case-by-case basis), unit stacking can get annoying to some, especially if playing pvp (you can bring 10 knights to a city and your opponent may have 50 spearmen in there), and a lot of the tool tips and advice online is vague. For example, corruption is very vaguely explained, but basically production and commerce will be thrown away to varying degrees based on government type, generally proximity to your capital (though Communism gives an exception), and number of cities in your empire (the more cities, the more corruption will become a factor up to a certain unspecified cap). Also, if playing pvp, if someone gets large enough, turns start taking large amounts of time, so I believe there is a timer feature, but depending on how you look at it, it could be an unfair penalty to someone doing well with a military approach, or it could be a handicap on a player that is doing too well to make the game more balanced.

Also, this may just be me, but the game can and will crash on Windows 10 (usually fairly predictable, though, at victory screen and potentially at startup). Also, there is a feature that's supposed to show events on the world map at the victory screen, but that entire feature was bugged on my last playthrough (the cities appeared on the map prior to their founding, and pointers to events didn't appear at all, though cultural boundaries showed up properly). I haven't had it randomly crash mid game, so it at least seems very stable there.

Still, really enjoy this game coming back to it. Highly recommend if you think that the newer civs feel slow due to little map movement or if you just want a bit of nostalgia or some context on how far Civ has come.

This is obviously a classic. It's a great game and it will go down into history. Also, I didn't like it.

Why? Because once I've played other Civ games I can see it's shortcomings and to be fair I cannot find an excuse to play it other than a newer one. It's not only about missing features or clarity, either.

Firstly, I hate the strategy necessary to beat this game. It's always expanding like a madman leaving everything behind but rushing settlers and workers with enough military to defend them while trading techs to the AI. That's it. You have a wide territory, you have a tech lead, and with so many  towns that you can effectively have hundreds of units out. That takes hundreds of turns and it's kind of boring and repetitive.

It was groundbreaking and incredible when I was younger, but after being spoiled by having to actually think very hard about funding new cities and having everything in order or risking falling behind; and having all of my builds make a difference instead of crapping out settlers... I'll sadly have to say the Classic was improved upon in my subjective opinion.

That said; it's pretty cheap; and still probably better than Civ VI (again, my opinion); but not better than Civ V or IV. It definitely deserves being bought and all of its positive reviews; I simply can't leave a positive one without being a liar.

This is NOT the Civ III that you used to play. The "complete" version turned the game even on the easiest setting into an impossible mess. As soon as any AI meets you, they instantly hate you and turn on you, regardless of the settings, even least aggressive. No such thing as "friendly" or "polite". It's just "OH! It's YOU!!!", then they usually demand something outrageous, and then they declare war and attack you with swarms of units there is no way that they actually built. You can have units that are 3 generations ahead of another player, and it will take 3 of them to make even a dent in 1 of theirs. 1 of their warriors will take out several of your medieval infantry without a problem. Doesn't matter what land your tile is, you get no defensive bonuses. You could have any fortified units on top of a mountain, and a warrior will happily tear through you like you're made out of tissue paper. Not to mention they can build whatever they want regardless of resources, and they don't have to fund or pay for units, so 1 city can create dozens of units every couple of turns. No matter how good you are, you can't withstand a swarm of several dozen units that are overpowered, and have the strength of industrial era weapons, attacking your cities each and every turn from the very beginning. And that's on the easiest settings!!! I'm all for a challenge, but at least make it a realistic challenge that is even remotely in the vicinity of fair. Might also be nice to be able to focus on other areas of the game like culture or science, as opposed to the game just always being one big, neverending melee set to the tune of Slayer's War Ensemble. So go find a disc version that's not this Complete one. The "Complete" means "Complete Garbage".

Nope, sorry. I liked the original Civilization from the early 90's. This effort though technically better with a lot more content, just falls flat. It has none of the charms of Civ 1, in fact I found Civ 3 to be dull and tedious.
The UI simply stank. One simple reason for this is it not allowing you the standard "right click to DESELECT unit". So you always had a unit selected - and as a result often clicked somewhere on the map and off it went, moving to that spot when you did not want it to. So you go to correct it. You click said wrong move unit, but no...... can't select it because of "this unit has already moved", BUT what then happens is ANOTHER unit has become active, which the map did not autocentre on (so you had no idea it had automatically selected another unit), and it then starts with unwanted movement!
You probably don't understand all that - it's hard to put into words. But the terrible UI had me constantly wrong moving entire chains of units all over the place.
The UI is very "non-standard" and it is difficult to get any information regards anything conveniently. There isn't even a proper world map view - the only one you get is a tiny thumbnail sized map that is just a jumbled mess of colours.
You never know where the enemy is. You never know where anything is. You never have the "big picture". You never feel in control. You are constantly fighting your own ministers who are obsessed with building unneeded and extremely expensive "wonders" in every city!
Then comes the AI sides. Even on easiest level and lowest aggression, they just all gang up on you. They all stroke each other peckers, but give you the cold shoulder, refusing all diplomatic requests you make - and never offering any treaties or trades to you. They only contact you with one or two unfair tech trades at the start, and from then on it's only to make bullying demands and declare war. They all share techs and treaties with each other though - with great gusto!
Once one inevitably decides to go to war against you, ALL the others follow suit within the next few turns. They never go to war with each other.
All AI civs are also BRUTALLY, profanely cheating, expansionists. This kind of AI is anathema to my usual style and I loathe and detest it. In Civ 3 this AI style is *all* you get....... every game ends the same after 100-200 turns, no matter how aggressively you try to expand, the AI teams just fills up the whole world with one giant "anti-YOU" alliance and all declare war and crush you.
This unfairness ruins Civ III. I just had to quit/uninstall in frustration. 
The graphics are also rather bland, nay, downright ugly - the civ leader portraits are a joke - and the music is awful.

Extremely disappointing, I expected so much more from this game. Lets not mince words, I loathed it.

And as for 99% of the reviewers around here thinking the sun shines out this game's arse, well they're wrong! It shows how intelligent these reviewers are when hundreds of them are spam that just say "relaxing", "gud game", "is fun", "classic" - hell, one spam review even just said "."! Others tell outright LIES such as "every game is different"...... no every game ends in the cheating AI civs all ganging up on you.

It's reviews like these that fool people into wasting their money on dog shit like Civ 3!

There are new, better, and more exciting games out there. So if you prefer that, then this game isn't for you. However, if you really like old classic games, then this is a good one to have. What I like about this old relic is the simple, slow paced, and somewhat out-dated game play. The graphics and special features are no longer advanced by today's standards, but they're still good enough to capture your imagination. The game starts of slow, but gets more exciting as the game advances. Interestingly, the beginning and most boring part of the game is the most critical. If you're like me and prefer to dominate through military force, every action matters. The most satisfying part of the game is proving your superiority by conquering other civilizations, especially when the AI gangs up on you. Be warned: Don't start what you can't finish. AI players love to gang up on human players.

[h1]Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36214917/]Curator Group for more reviews[/url][/h1]
Sid Meier's Civilization III holds classic status for a lot of people, and for good reason. Given its age, it holds up suprisingly well. If this review was only comparing it to its contemporaries, Civilization III would get a perfect score. Unfortunately, when compared to later Civilization games, it begins to falter. The biggest knock against Civilization III isn't really an issue with the game, its just that later games build on its foundation so well. Now that we are on the 6th game in the franchise, there is an entry for everyone. If people want the most modern, sleek, and optimized version of Civilization, they can play 6. If they want an old school feel they can play 4. And if they want a sort of middle ground, the 5th game does a great job balancing those 2 elements. For Civilization III, it plays a lot like Civ 4 but with some pretty popular mechanics missing. To me, Civ 3 doesn't really have a niche that it excels at, and that's why I can't recommend it. Every feature is done better in a different Civ game, leaving little reason for me to revisit it 20 years later.

So I first want to preface this that I am baised against this game. This is one of the very first game I ever watched some one play and I have very fond memories of sitting next to my dad watching him play this game for hours so it has a very special place in my heart.

Now that being said this game is the Civilization game you should play if your interested in a aggressive empire building strategy where you want to win through domination or by conquering every other nation in the game. From what I've heard civ six and five kind of drop the war aspect and I can tell form experience that Civ fours military strategy is kind of lacking when compared to civ three. This is in part due to later games kind of getting rid of the "special unit". In civ three every nation has a unique unit that only they can build and each one of them is differrent and offers an improvement over the regular version any other nation can unlock. These units can be a complete game changer for you and your conquest and thus choosing which nation to play as is beyond important as you have to decide about important factors such as what do you wan as a special unit and does it come to late for it to make a differrence in my game.  This game has solid graphics for the time it came out and very good music. 
As all other civ games it's a very good and fun strategy game where you can sink hours into with out even realizing.  
To sum up I would recommend this Civilization game for two reasons one its currently the cheapest on steam and it has to best combat strategy. The later game kind of abandon this part of the game. So if your looking for an empire building game and are interested in nothing else then conquering and destroying every other nation then this is the civ game for you.  If not I would recommend you look at the later civ games.

I've played this game on and off for years, ever since the 'Gold Edition' launched in 2003.

It's easy to pick up, and absorbs your time as you race to expand your civilisation through a combination of growth and military conquest. Various civilisations provide different bonuses which cater to different play styles and strategies. For example, you can gain military bonuses to build large armies, scientific bonuses to facilitate technological advantages, commerce bonuses to offset whatever costs you decide to incur, as well as others.

You can customise the game such as map size and type, AI difficulty, types of victories and accelerated production for a quicker game. Note that large maps often end up taking a lot of time and turns become longer and longer as you manage large numbers of cities and units. Also on harder difficulties, rather than implementing optimum strategies, the AI receives bonuses and becomes ridiculously hard.

If you get bored of the standard random maps, you can load various scenarios that come with the game. There is even a quite comprehensive map editor which allows for custom maps and rules. You can create your own custom resources, units, techs, governments and civilisations. It's even possible with just the map editor to build cities on water.
It is a social chess game that allow you to determine the path of your selected civilization.

In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#267 out of 612)... it's time for Sid Meier's Civilization III.

Arguably the most important, if not the best, entry in the venerable Civilization series. While today Civilization 5 may be the definitive version of Civilization, Civilization III used to claim that spot, and is still very much worth revisiting today--especially if you're looking to play Civ on an older PC that might groan and creak under the strain of modern games.

Civilization III is incredibly polished and boasts an enormous amount of content, especially with regard to mods. The 2D visuals still look gorgeous today and a modern CPU can bruteforce its way through that usual murderer of Civilization playthroughs, the late-game slog. Be warned, however, that Civilization III is a very old game, and it shows its age. Mostly this manifests in the UI, which is considerably less intuitive and clear than we're accustomed to these days--and, perhaps most problematically for new players, there aren't any tooltips. If you've never played a Civilization game before, you're in for a steep learning curve. And if it's been a while since you've played Civilization III and you're looking to revisit an old favorite, well, unless your memory is much greater than mine, odds are you'll have a fair bit of a learning curve to muddle through as well. Who'd've thought the most important innovation in the 4x genre over the last 20 years would be something as simple as tooltips?

Well, anyway. It's Civilization III: one of the finest turn-based strategy games ever produced. In many respects it falls short of its successors, most notably the wildly imaginative expansions of Civilization IV and the perfectly polished systems and mechanics of Civilization V, but it remains an excellent title nonetheless.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

If you want a simpler version of Civ, I can't recommend CIV III enough. It is quicker to learn, and much easier to pickup than modern civilization games. Perfect for beginners, and as you can see, I go back all the time when I need a break from other strategy games. The AI isn't too timid and there are trading options that make some of the other Civ games seem lacking. The trading system's simplicity is a big draw, and the lack of other peripherals such as religion and city states allow you to focus on building up your cities and armies.

I failed to take heed of other commenters who warned about the incompatibility issues. I regret making the mistake of purchasing and installing this game, believing that I would not suffer the same problems. Not the case. The game, in its current condition, is severely bugged (but it is also specified in "System Requirements" section of Steam that the game is compatible with Win2000/XP only).

Second problem: The game's AI settings apparently have been changed greatly since when I was playing the basic version of it from a CD, many years ago. I distincly remember how the difficulty would scale in a reasonable manner as you went up in difficulty settings. Not anymore. Probably due to the influence of the modding community, which I suspect would be hardcore gamers, even at the easiest settings the AI is completely focused on spamming cities and units, without a thought for developing their cities. I remember playing around the hardest difficulty settings before. In this version, even at the easiest settings any other civilizations you play against gang up on you from the get go.

I was still greatly pleased with reading the many civilopedia entries and visiting the nice memories of the old appearance of the game. However, I believe it is a broken piece of software now. And considering that it is almost an ancient game today, and that it has had 3 more sequels so far, I don't think any improvements will take place.

I do not recommend this game in its current condition.

This is a great quarantine game!  Steam breathed new life into it with updated internet play since the old gamespy internet play was gone.  So you can grind your friends' civilizations into the dirt for hours of fun :-)  Watch out when some of them claim they're just going past to look somewhere else- they may be gathering for a sneak attack without honorably declaring war first!  Plus truly anyone can play, probably ANY Windows machine alive today can run this old game and with the price dirt cheap no one can whine that it's too expensive.  Google for the "KeepRes" ini setting for better screen resolution.

This game can be finicky in the intro and end cut scenes (sometimes freezing the game up from continuing), but the game allows for some intricate victory conditions, and even map setup, to give your chosen civilization either an edge or a challenge. With a gamut of nations, from Rome to Japan, to play as, each with their own unique units and traits, there is never a shortage of replayability and fun. This, and Alpha Centuari, are good choices for those who want to dip their toe into the TBS genre from the genius of Sid Meier without having to spend a lot of money. Overall, this is TBS at its finest.

Civ 3 was the breakthrough for this classic turn-based strategy franchise. It's just detailed enough as to be intuitive, while not getting overly complicated as the later games in the series. Easy to pick up; hard to put down. Civ 3 was a childhood favorite that occupied hours at a time, and picking it up again after 10+ years is a real treat. It takes small storage and downloads in minutes (hooray for old games!). The graphics and AI are poor, but the nostalgia stands strong. As long as you can bear with the occasional crashes (it maybe didn't age so well? save often!), you'll get a great experience with a most excellent game.

This is a fantastic strategy game against "fair" AI player, until one of the civilizations suddenly acquires "cheat" level power and wealth. All countries were similar within reason. I just quit after a long "building process". One of the opposing countries suddenly advanced to high level mechanics. My horse cavalry was being attacked by aircraft, automatic weapons, and tanks. No fun. Very disappointing. Happens every time. Too bad, otherwise a great game with simple, responsive graphics. Later versions have "silly", cartoon-like  graphics and are not as responsive.

Tried once again. After advancing into the industrial age, my AI opponents suddenly gained huge advances. Once again, found my horse cavalry defending against mechanized armored units and aircraft. When I viewed their technology, a few rounds earlier, we were almost even in terms of advancement. Very frustrating to work so hard, only to have the AI civs cheat! May try the cartoon style later versions, but they are not as nimble as the older version.
consume

The game is very clunky and the 'tutorial' mode offers no help with most of the issues. The biggest problem i had were with an apparent unbalanced scaling in how the AI nations behave, even in the easiest mode. THey expand continuously with apparently no concern for territory or money. This further creates a problem when they settle cities between yours and comlain every time your troops move through the region as they HAVE TO DO to go anywhere. 
Another issue is lack of clarity in how to or ability to deal with internal issues such as civil disorder. The corruption mehanic doent mke a lot of sense and there doesnt see to be anything the player can do to minimize it except literally build all your cities directly around your capitol, which while strategically may be ideal, seriously limits expansion prospects. Building roads is a suggested mitigation move, but it doesn't appear to actually do anything. it's also apparently impossible to actually maintain or affect where the money in your cities goes.

Greatest game ever.  Only 2 real issues that I have ever had problems with.  #1  Automated exploring is idiotic.  If you send two units out they always end up in the same area or retrace their steps for 10 turns to make it back to one overlooked square they missed earlier instead of continuing into unexplored areas.  #2  Sometimes battles against vastly inferior opponents ends up with them winning.  E.G.  4 units with attacks of 4 go against 3 units with defenses of 2.  The attackers are wiped out.  This consistently happens in Civ, where a vastly superior unit is defeated by a vastly inferior unit.  I just sing a diddy, "the impossible last stand, the spearman defends his land, against waves of swordsmen, it's the impossible last stand."  That's how often it happens, I made up a silly song.  Other than that, I've never played a game more in my life.

Amazing Game! Best instillation in the franchise if you ask me! A fun RTS with many factions to pick from (I believe it's 31 to be exact)! Enjoying making my own maps and playing them. Accessing the editor is a little difficult at first because you don't open it through steam, but your file browser instead (There's forums for this if you're interested)! The game is built upon many aspects which gives it a unique play-stile where you get to manage your Economy, Culture, Military, Diplomacy, Science/Technological advancements throughout the Bronze age, Midieval era, the Middle ages, The industrial era, the Modern era and beyond! Definately a 5/5 for me! And it certainly takes it's place among my top 10 game franchises along with The total war series, Halo, Call of Duty, Fortnite, Tomb Raider, Uncharted, Resistance, Men of War, Command and Conquer, and Star wars Battlefront! Definitely worth the money! Enjoy folks! Oh, and also, the difficulty varies significantly with the eight or so different levels, so for those of you who love a challenge, this game's for you! For those who want to easily walk all over their opressors, this game's for you! And for all of those who love their games so hard that all they ever do is get their butt's whooped, This games for you!

I wish I could recommend this game, but it has changed so much. I played the "normal" edition (less playable civilizations, simpler mechanics, etc) of Civ 3 for 100s of hours as a kid. The game seems very unbalanced, there are some bugs when talking to other civilizations (Windows 10), and it was just genuinely harder than it used to be even on the easiest settings. ...Well, on a sale of 1 to 10 in difficulty, I place it roundabouts a 8.5, because, and I actually have played longer on another account, in the 3 years I've been attempting to beat "Easy" mode, I have done so exactly 0 times. Maybe Im a terrible player, but, warning issued. Prepare to be stymied.
 One complaint I might have is the balancing mechanics between AI and the Player. Unless you go aggressive expansionist, or seclude yourself from the rest of the AI, you will be dominated swiftly. Is there really any chance of success if you spawn next to an AI? No. They will get out 12 Archers before you can build One measly Warrior.
 Otherwise, it's a great game, but If you'd want more winnability, try out CIV5. If you're a "do or die" Masochist who wants to prove their strategic genius, may the odds be ever in your Favor. This is the game for you.

Don't be fooled by the number above, I have more than 3k hours played at least. On the the review now:

I've been playing on and off since it's release. I've learned a lot of history and English terminology through playing this game as a kid. The game play is not the best: the next games are superior game play wise. However they eliminated the endless combat that reigns over Civ 3. It is one of these games, uniquely so, that you can hoard military units, stack them up near the enemy's borders, declare war and take 5 cities, big or small, before the enemy gets his turn. Although a lot, A LOT, of micromanagement is required to pull off this kind of tactic, it is really rewarding if somewhat tedious. The technology system is fine, it's slower than later games, but you have more time to play between eras. Most unique units are well-designed. A lot of Wonders are broken (Statue of Zeus, cough cough) and can allow you to cut through early eras like a knife through butter. Early eliminations are common and wonder fights are exciting. 

The OST is BONKERS. I still listen to it, so many years later, even without playing. Jungle sounds, mesoamerican music etc. Really well orchestrated.

Overall, I've been enjoying this game for so many years. It's my childhood darling so I may be a bit far from objectively measuring its pros and cons.
One of my longtime favorites. Time and resource managment are key. And i actually really enjoy the animations and characterizations of the different nations.

Each time I started the game to check on some detail, six hours mysteriously vanished. Perfectly captures the epic sweep of the previous games but adds a bunch of new features that improve upon an already brilliant concept. It's superior in every way to "Civilization II". The interface is much better implemented this time around...To make a long story short, Civ. III is a worthy heir for the franchise and a definite must have for any strategy gamer.
The UI is difficult to understand (especially unit amounts/strength/health), and the internet will be of no use to you in terms of tutorials, but otherwise it seems like and okay game.

Incredibly biased opinion since this is based on nostalgia (still have played a lot even now) but I love this game to death. Later civs really try hard to develop things like diplomacy, religion, social policies etc. but I'm out for global domination which is very possible in this game unlike later ones where they make it much more difficult and I'd say they actively discourage it.  I bought this as a backup copy, what does that tell you?).  I couldn't recommend it enough back in the day, but it's a bit older, and thus the graphics aren't as high.  The later editions added things like vassal states, which you can turn off, but I never liked, and I like to play with all rules on. So, in that case, older is better!

Coming from Civ V as my first Civ game - well, technically it was Civ Revolution but let's pretend that didn't happen -, I found this game enjoyable. In my limited experience so far though, there seems to be less things to do, however the present mechanics are on a larger scale. For example, there are no social policies but a few government types, religion only in the form of a few religious buildings I guess but nothing customizable and so on. Though on the other hand, you build far more cities and mass produce units, often the same things over and over. It's the same things with workers, for the most part you build roads and either irrigation or mines on the tiles. Overall, the core experience looks like it's the enjoyable same, but a simpler zen-like experience. I could also run the game on both Windows 7 and Windows 10 both x64 just fine, resolution is also ok.

civ3 creates an impression that is it much more designed for robots than humans

it seems as well AI acts with perfect knowledge of map (which is nearly the only strong way to heavily cheat on this without some quadruple bonuses to everything, however all those are a thing on top difficulty i bet; and in those old civs you pretty sure are not winning in this absurd case)

it seems AI doesn't really try to unite against you in case of lead (though maybe does get furious at riches), yet is overly happy to try silly backstabs / 'surprise attacks' or else; it may even try to assault clearly later era stronghold with simple hordes that would almost never win there

oh and there's the quite massive downside in old civ - combat is literally random, so much that it matters almost endlessly, since there are massive terrain bonuses as well and ancient spearmen could very well beat tanks; it's not even a weird and rare case - hopelessly outdated AI hordes may just jump onto your mountains anytime and become unmovable force

there is a lot of inconvenience with units such as limits to upgrading, mostly no true way to skip tons of unit movements and such (maybe in case of railroads it becomes sort of that), while there are tons of units and often clumsy or limited control over them - and then 'same continent' is breaking minds of automated workers, there was a case where they literally rushed through many foreign borders and large lands that are hostile - to sometimes work on nearly or actually foreign volcano that recently exploded - and then instantly all die to yet another explosion, while they stand right on top of volcano

AIs for some reason barely ever wish to cooperate anyhow equally, even if it's them who often try to ally their weak nation to much more advanced one - even if it's exactly they who backstabbed you and awfully need protection now - of course it's you who always should pay army's worth of upkeep in protection treaty; then there's both positive and strange moment - bots can be (furious) at you yet still seriously try to ally and get protection

civ3 is somehow quite confusing and unintuitive i suppose, even when simultaneously tools available + core mechanics are ridiculously simple (but even pacing is very strange); it also seems to take massive time to playthrough even a bit - and without much management i guess (spammy) AI and all those older type mechanics can result in a quick death of civilization

it did have some nice ideas but the rest can simply create rather stupid spammy - defensive-favoring (and as well ruining that for YOU the player, because you lack any extra automation possible) grind, starting even from most ancient times where first of all units can be massed and rushed by population that generally anyone has and some do in massive surplus

overall civ3 has either too serious or too numerous problems to be offset by a few good moments; i'd say in practice it is easily nearly unplayable, inconvenient and quite mindless - while serious business going on against you won't let you be mindless one (or there you could lose on the easiest setting possible); it is possibly not even really challenging since maps feature very inhospitable lands (full of mountains not to even settle or ever grow anything) while as well rich and useful plains

so from the start it seems about all factors are against you; that's somewhat interesting but not for long (and that's a bit too much patience still)

since it is often not even easy to survive - some a bit casual or even a much later civ5 player will likely be plainly outspammed by ruthless AI if they miss about anything in proper setup and management (and when unfamiliar, there must be a lot to miss)

Sid Meier's Civilization III is the de-facto greatest game in terms of basic graphics and gameplay-wise, especially in the entire Sid Meier's Civilization series. It brung more things the other two didn't implement, such as animated leaders, advisors, and updated isometric view, and brand new land graphics simulating the real world, and even coastlines.

This version, however, is the greatest buy I have ever accomplished. You got editors, and other civilizations bundled with this! It has all three expansions, and adds a functioning multiplayer! I love this game and it even competes with my love for Civilization IV. I just love it, and you guys should get it at any opportunity, such as sales and special events.

This game is a good starting point for newcomers to the Civilization series and currently the best value for money. It is fully compatible with modern systems and still worth playing today. The visual aesthetic of the game is one of its best features, and I still consider III to be the best looking Civilization game, due to its appealing artstyle and readability.

Civ III lacks some of the sophisticated gameplay mechanics introduced in the later games and I consider the combat in particular to be a weaker point of this game, as it usually amounts to just mindlessly building more units than your opponents. Despite this, Civ III gets the job done simply and effectively, which is why I always come back to it over the other games in the series. The Conquests scenarios are an interesting addition to the game and I have replayed them countless times. There are also numerous custom scenarios and mods available. If you have an interest in history and like strategy games, I would fully recommend Civilization III.

I absolutely hate this game. I've played Call to Power 1 and 2, Sid Meier's Civ 5, 6, and this. I see all these reviews about how this is still the best Civ game, and I just do not see what they're seeing. In Civ 5 and 6, the enemy AI will at least kill and absorb far weaker AI. They will at least every once in awhile do little pretend wars where they attack another equal AI's city (not take it, but just damage it ). The enemy AI in this game will always be permanently allied against you, even if you pick for them to be the least aggressive they can be (useless option). The combat is the most frustrating, rng-based, tedious, time-consuming, micro-managing ****fest I've ever seen. You can have many units occupy a tile, but they can only attack 1 at a time. You would think that means combat would at least be better than Civ 5 and 6, but like I said, the rng is so stupid that you have to make sure you have an advantage of 5x or more, unless you want to just load half the time and try the battle again, cuz you will fail half the time at a 2x advantage. And what I mean by that is this - You can have a unit with twice as much attack as they have defense, they can be wounded, sitting in a grassland/plain, not fortified, not across a river, and there's still a good chance you will lose if you attack him. In addition to that, you can NOT fully kill an enemy by bombarding. This means that you have to rely on rng attacking to actually kill any enemy military unit. Call to Power 2 sucks because you can't set up a scenario where the AI put up any threat (they won't attack you with anything more than a few units ever), and this game sucks for the opposite reason, because the AI only wants you dead and they have huge advantages even on low difficulties. It especially doesn't help that the maps spawn such few horses and iron (even though you NEED them to get anything past starting units in this game), seems to always put them near the AI and far away from you, and punishes you greatly if you build a town far away from your own (through waste/corruption penalties), in which, you would need to connect that town with a road in order to build those horse/iron units in your other towns. If you don't connect that town to your civilization, then like I said, the waste/corruption is so bad that you won't get to build ANYTHING in that town. The enemy AI also destroys your lonely roads in no time. I'm uninstalling this game and never considering it again. BLIZZARD, PLEASE PUT CALL TO POWER 1 UP FOR DIGITAL DOWNLOAD, SO I CAN ACTUALLY HAVE FUN AGAINST AI AGAIN!

P.S.

Runs perfectly on Linux (Ubuntu 16.04 with 2560 x 1440 resolution monitor).

P.P.S.

To run in Linux:

a)
On a steam client go to "Steam > Settings > Steam Play" and check option "Enable Steam Play for all titles".

b)
Run a game first time - it probably won't start if You have large resolution monitor like me, but thats alright - the first run will create a conquests.ini (~/.steam/steam/steamapps/common/Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete/Conquests/conquests.ini) file.

Put these lines in that file:

KeepRes=1
PlayIntro=0

Save changes and play now till you drop dead.

Sid Meier's Civilization III is a turn-based strategy game on where you can play as one of many nations/countries and play on various maps which would be the "Earth" for that map. This complete edition concludes of the base game, Civilization III, Civilization III Play the World & Civilization III Conquest. We have many scenarios in this game with examples of them being Rise of Rome, World War 2 Pacific and even Earth type maps which you can either have true starting locations as your desired nation or have the spawn randomized. 

PROS
- CIv 3 has the biggest maps out of any other Civ game.
- We have no limitations on units like we had on every sequel. Units can stack which gave a much more war feeling to the game.
- If you want a game to last at least a week or even a month. On this game you can make it happen.
- For an old game it still runs smoothly.
- Multiplayer still works, so you can play with friends and/or family.
- Gameplay is simple, but you can make mistakes easily and the enemy will take advantage of that 

CONS
- Dated graphics (can be a + or a -)

Overall
This is and always will be my favourite civ 3 game, the sequels are all about fancy graphics and less war. If you want to actually feel like you have a civilization then this is the game for you. If you want the ultimate experience, on an earth map and the biggest map you can dream of. Then pick this map. TETurkhan Test of Time. This comes with various game types that include of spawning with pre-made cities like earth is today with the available civilizations in the game, true location start which allows you to where your country's first capital was. Or have it randomized. So you could have England in India or the Japanese in Africa. This is the biggest map the game has to offer and with the size of it. You are talking at least a couple of weeks to finish, if you plan to go with a total domination game. Well I'ma say it'll take you a little over a month.

I've been coming back to this game year after year.  Civ IV, V, and VI have tended to streamline play and take on a more multiplayer-oriented mindset, which is great if that's what you want; but I keep coming back for Civ 3 for its month-long games, detail, and versatility.  I'll concede the vanilla game isn't the best (though the built-in scenarios are fun), but over the years I've edited the default scenario to a point that fits my playstyle: more resources types, greater differentiation in terrain, more divergent unit types, more engaging naval forces, and a modern era that holds a bit more interest.

I think this is my favorite Cic game, I only  have a few hours played, but I had it before I got it on steam.  This was a huge improvement over Civ 2.  The ability to turn other factions cities in the middle if you empire thanks to culture was a much needed improvement.  Hex also made for smoother  movement, in addition managing where citizens worked in a city was supper easy, its also the last on to stop being that easy (not sure about Civ 4, i skiped that one).  For the most part units are the same as Civ 2, except now each civ has a unique unit, some more useful than others since some are only useful on the "BC eras" while other are far better in the "modern era" (a chariot vs F15).  Each civ also has bonuses to various stats, such as faster navel units or a science research bonus. The xpacs add some nice content, but to me they seem t make the game end faster, but that could just be from being engrossed in the game. 

Civ 5 and Beyond Earth are good (as  is Civ 6 Im sure), each has their own things that make it better, but in the end Civ 3 is at the top of my list, even if i dont play it as much as the other ones right now.

I've played Civ3, Civ4, Civ5, and Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri (also known as SMAC).  Civ3 and SMAC are still the best of these to me.  I wish Steam had the full version of SMAC, cuz I never was able to get the expansion pack for that one.

I got THIS version of Civ3 as part of a package deal.  I already had a CD-ROM of the original game and played that a lot.  I had plans to hunt down the expansion packs for it as well, but then Steam came into my life.

I compare playing Civ3 to a Poker tournament.  It's pretty easy to learn how to play, and hard to win in the long run.  Despite all the hours I've put into it, I've never won a game, even when I thought I was supposed to.  The point isn't to win, though; the point is to play.  Every time I've done that, I've learned something else.  I've also quit many games due to the fact that it was obvious I had been dealt a losing start.  Replay value approaches the infinite due to the sheer number of variables that go into a game, most of which are customizable, and some of which are procedurally generated (including the map, which will make or break you most times).

I was hoping that Civ4 and Civ5 would prove to be closer to this game and SMAC combined.  That turned out not to be the case.  Because of my love for this game and SMAC, I've found it difficult to enjoy 4 and 5 for what they offer.  They didn't feel like improvements on the formula, TBH.  I say that cuz, well, Civ3 is just that frickin' good.

For me, Civ3 is a fine, and also somewhat extreme, example of how gameplay is superior to graphics.  I can't say that pining for the days of sprites is in everyone's best interest; but sometimes, awesome polygonal renderings are just too much, or they wind up being more of a hindrance or distraction.  That said, Civ3 is not particulary known for its awesome sprites, either.  Still, you know what is what in this game.  Plenty of people made mods for the game as well.  I've seen Lord of the Rings mods, and one or two intended to improve how terrain features looked.  I never got into these, myself, although I do wish some things were easier to see due to design.

If you like strategy games, or are looking to try one, give Civ3 a shot, or let it be your introduction.
Its the best civ game in my opinion.

My original experience with Civilization and without a doubt my favorite. First got the game from my parents back in 2004 and rebought it on Steam back in 2015. The game is easy to pick up and hard to put down, and contains the right level of complexity to make it strategically pleasing but not overly complicated. I would argue it's the best way to blow 2-4 hours (especially if the internet is down).

This game is a gem.. it delivers a unique atmosphere and enjoyment that no other civ managed to equal, not even civ 6. 

PROS
- Each era contains its unique soundtrack, and nore of them are as boring as the soundtracks of civ 5 and civ 6. 
- You want to conquer a city? Go for it, send in a ton of units and take it.. your offensive units vs your enemy's defensive units, no insane bonus for defending a city and no ridiculous penalties for capturing as many cities as you want (looking at you civ 5). 
- The fact that you can stack as many units as you want on a single stack was a vital mechanic that civ 5 should have never taken away.. it makes the game clunky and unnecessarily limitating.
- All units have 2 values, an offensive one and a defensive one, allowing for more complex strategies and making every units a lot more unique and specialized. 

CONS
The AI will be unforgiving and sooner or later, every single one of them will swarm you will armies aimed at ending you.. it can be very challenging for players who like to simply give up when things get difficult, because they will. They progress very quickly with science, just to make things even more difficult. For this reason, i strongly suggest new players to choose the easiest level of difficulty at first, or maybe the one after it for players who played a lot with other civs. 

CONCLUSION
Every mistakes that civ5's developpers made, the ones that we hoped were going to be fixed in civ 6.. well, this game will give you an experience of a vastly more satisfying and authentic civ game. after playing this game and enjoying it, you'll feel like civ5 took the wrong turn and civ6 will no longer be relevant to you.

This is a classic Civ game, but with a classic flaw. The game cheats and cheats hard. By cheating the games AI will settle cities miles away from their territory and right next to yours. Thus forcing you to fight to keep your land free. Then after a few dozen turns they will send in a few stacked armies that almost always will desimate your troops.

Now this cheat isn't impossible to beat, but the deadly troop stack will sooner or later spell doom for you and your civ. Only real way around this cheat is to get an island, stay isolated as long as possible, and then hold out.

In the end having to play the game in isolation is boring and results in this game being a dud.

Civ 3 is a great entry in the series, but there are some reasons why it doesn't hold up to the newer games. First is the combat and how the only viable defensive strategy is stacking all your units in your cities. The no military unit stacking rule starting in Civ V is such a simple and huge advancement. Second is how bad the AI is. The AI is just terrible compared the newer games. Third is that the quanitity of your cities is better than the quality. It is always the better option to settle as many cities as possible, even within your own borders. What keeps me coming back to this game is the nostalgia, the scenarios, and the simplicity. I love playing the WWII Pacific, New World, and Napoleonic Wars scenarios. For how cheap you can get this game there is no reason a Civ fan should not have this in their library.

I need to be careful not to play this game too often. When I do play, I get sucked in for hours on end; it's so addictive. I used to own the CD-ROM set years ago - a gift from my brother. Over time, the CDs got scratched, and I was wary when buying this game. I remembered the addictive effects it had on me in high school - staying up all hours of the night, every night. This time around, I can handle it better. If anyone out there is considering buying this game, just be careful - set yourself a timer based on the maximum limit you're willing to let yourself play in any given night. Otherwise, you'll keep playing until you crash, and you'll end up missing school, being late for work, and ignoring UFOs passing overhead.

I have played a lot of Civ games, from Advanced Civilizations on DOS all the way up to the brand new Civ VI. And this is still my favorite of all of them. It is definitely not the prettiest or most user-friendly civ game, but its grit and punishing difficulty (at the higher settings) give it a realism lost in a lot of the newer Civ games.  That being said the game is a huge leap foward from a lot of its easier counterparts, though it's still not as difficult at Advanced Civilizations, you don't need to mount your C:/ Drive to play it and there is a manual... Stupid RNG no explanation Civil Wars...

Anyway, long story short:
If you are new to the Civilization Franchise I might recommend starting with  Civ V, its an easier more friendly game. That being said, if you are a veteran of the franchise or of the strategy genre, Civ III will give you a more difficult, more immersive, and more brutal experience, and is well worth the $1-$5 it costs.

Sid Meier's Civilization III is a turn-based conquering game that is really fun to play.
 
  Before you actually start the game, you need to choose the kind of world you want, such as choosing the size, the weather and the planet's age, after that you must choose one of the many available nations to play with, each having their unique traits.

  You can play with bots or real-life players, choosing the team in which you want them and yourself to be, thus having allies and enemies in combat.

  And as a final note, don't stare too much at the leaders, or else they are going to consume your soul, except for Theodora of course! <3

  Therefore I recommend this game to everyone interested on strategy games! :D

This game is everything I want out of the Civilization series, even if a bit dated. The graphics have aged fairly well in my opinion, especially for a game from the very early 2000s. The old map-like aesthetic of the game's empire view is very nice, and the unit sprites are done very well for a game from a time with extremely limited graphical capabilities. One feature I especially love that I think shouldn't have been done away with in future Civilization games is the 'aerial view', which allows you to get an extremely detailed view of your cities.

However, even if the graphics are considered lackluster by some in this time, the soundtrack still holds up extremely well and is possibly the best soundtrack out of the entire Civilization series. From the piano-based melodies of the Medieval era to the jazzy guitar riffs of the Modern era, the soundtrack is extremely immersive and well-produced. Even some DLC scenarios have custom soundtracks, which are just as well-made as the soundtracks of the main game.

The gameplay is also well-done and it isn't too easy, nor is it too hard. The difficulty scaling in this game works well enough, and you are able to even change specifics such as AI aggressiveness, something that appears to be absent from later entries in the series. The advisors in this game are actually quite helpful and their associated menu screens allow you to easily get a detailed overview of your empire in order to best manage it. My only criticism of the more domestic side of gameplay is the way corruption works in this game; it tends to be quite rampant (especially on larger maps, and ESPECIALLY in the later stages of the game) although it can be reduced with wonders such as the Forbidden Palace and buildings such as courthouses.

Combat in this game is based off of an RNG system that works fairly well, although there is the occasional absolutely ludicrous outcome where a spearman will manage to defeat a tank. Unit promotions in this game work on four levels: conscript (the starting level for conscripted units as well as units gifted by villages), regular (the starting level for built units), veteran, and elite. Each promotion grants an extra bar of health. While much more simple than the extensive promotions in games such as Civilization 5, this system still works quite well as Civilization 3 tends to focus much more on wider-scale combat and empire management than single-unit powerhouses.

Overall, Civilization 3 is an excellent -- albeit, somewhat dated -- entry into the Civilization series. I'd probably give up both of my legs to see a remastering of this game.

My favorite Civilization title of all time. This game may be old, but I find it's graphics are just right for the genre and it does not have the cartoony look that some later titles are sometimes guilty of. Being an older title, the AI isn't always the smartest and will struggle to perform certain tasks like sea-based invasions. A huge problem with this game is its infamous RNG which has led to powerful units being killed by weaker unit (i.e. spearman kills tank). However, just play without "preserve random seed" enabled and you can just save before each battle and reload quickly to get a better result if you feel you have been cheated. Other features missing include advanced diplomacy beyond war and trade and revolutions occuring in pre-established empires (a feature lacking from most unmodded Civ titles).

The thing that makes this game my favorite Civ is the availablity of mods to customize this game to your heart's content. You can play out just about any scenario you can think of. Although a lot of files were lost when civfanatics changed a while back, there is still plenty of diverse content available. I would highly recommend the WorldWide mod for anyone looking for a much expanded version of the game. Whether you want to make small changes like add in one or two units or a custom civ, or install total conversions and scenarios, the tutorials online make it very easy to add such things in.

I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Civilization and other empire-building RTS games.

I played Civilization V and Civilization IV, but for some reason I keep getting back to Civilization III.
It is a masterpiece that stands the test of time. It is more realistic and fun with huge maps. No religion, but best Nuclear Weapons, artillery mechanic, interface is great for me and Civilopedia is the best out of all Civilizations for me. Clear and Plain to understand.
Easy game to play, yet it is harder to master.
Advisors and Leaders change clothes, depending on which era it is. Interface is more "realistic" looking and not too cartonish as the newer ones. Music is outstanding.
A lot is early on about how much you expand, but it is also much easier to get steam rolled by opponents if your cities are not defended. Sometimes less better cities is more productive and efficient. Maps play a big role, and the map editor is amazing.
Diplomacy I found the most realistic of all. World war scenario can happen very quick with mutual protections. 
Never attack anyone however with open borders, they will hate you pretty much forever, lol.
If you are not the leading in technology you can still sell them to the one that have none. If you have a technology noone has, sell it to everyone (Like worldmaps) in the same turn. Extra money is great.
Governments are a very good mechanic too. Made no sense to me Civilization IV Police State with free speech.

I recommend this game to all lovers of strategy, history and nostalgic gamers.

Edit. P.S. Ignore my steam play hours, I have probably more than a thousand.

Add this :
KeepRes=1
to its own line in your ini file "./Civilization III Complete/Conquests/conquests.ini" to get proper widescreen support (non 4:3 aspect). This line used to be in Civ3PTW.ini but apparently got moved to this file at a later version. Depending on the version you have, this might be somewhere else too....perhaps one more directory down at "./Civilization III Complete/Conquests/Conquests/conquests.ini"

For Linux, see WineHQ for more info on how to get the "squaking" bird sound to stop once it starts. The quick fix is to turn off those sounds in options but slightly less enjoyable as it removes all the environment sounds. The short of what the fix entails is you just have to replace the bird sound file with a silent version which is easy enough to craft using something like audacity.

This game is great, but not as great as Civ5. It has pretty dated graphics and the leader animations are just downright ugly by today's standards. Some of the features are a little dated, too, like building roads to increase gold output and, of course, insane unit stacks. The music for the game isn't bad by the high standards of Civ, except the opening track which is so annoying I have to mute my speakers whenever it plays. 
This game, despite some of its dated features, is still a heck of a lot of fun. I relish the dated graphics as a "retro" Civ experience from 2001, and even the constant road-building gives your workers something to do in the later game. The "city view," which disappeared in Civ4, is something that I definitely wish would've been continued, as well as the palace view. It's also nice to be able to pass through civ borders without permission like the city-state borders from civ5, although this will anger the offended nation. I got it for $1.75 on sale and considering that's it the complete edition, it's worth every penny. 
The game is fun, cheap, and has a healthy dose of retro/nostalgic feeling for those who have played the newer Civ games. Considering that you can get this for less than two dollars, I definitely recommend this purchase.

Had to play with the grid visible most of the time, otherwise couldn't see shit. Didn't get used to the grid so switched it off from time to time... and again couldn't see crap.

Other than that, it is quite good Civ game and feels like much refined C2. I liked the concept of visible and expanding borders, rather disliked the idea of culture as a winning factor (yeah right, like this could happen in this dimension), loved the concept of strategic resources and linking cities by roads/harbors/airport to use them. If you did not play Civilization 3 in the past and are wondering if you should buy it - below is some basic info that should encourage you to do that.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
The pluses:

+ Lots of civilizations, each plays differently

+ Lots of different units + special military unit for each civilization

+ The AI scripts are demanding (unlike in most modern games)

+ Resources on map force you to play strategically

+ Depending on the size and type of the maps, games might differ quite a lot

+ You can play in really big maps

+ The game has fine mods that you can find on the internet

+ It's hard to stop playing it

------------------------------------------------------
The minuses:
- It's hard to stop playing it

- At higher difficulties the military victory is the most viable option (only)

- When you control most of the map it's just boring killing of the remaining weaklings

- At the industrial age, you probably control most of the map

- At higher difficulties AI is cheating

- Civilizations are not balanced (some are really good, some - really bad)

- After you learn to use workers and diplomacy, it's not that hard (but still fun)

- Old 2D game, so in native desktop resolution units and fonts might be too small

- Old 2D game, so in native game resolution units might be too big (and no widescreen)

======================================

For native desktop resolution in game:

1. Go to the Conquests folder in your Civ 3 folder conquests.ini
2. Put "keepRes=1" in conquests.ini file (without "")

======================================

Those settings should fix crashes in Windows 7 64 bit.

1. Go to the Conquests folder in your Civ 3 folder
2. Rename LSANS.FOT to -LSANS.FOT

If that does not help:
Set Windows compatibility to Windows XP Service Pack 2 and run program as administrator.

If the game runs too slow delete keepRes=1 from ini file (in Windows XP mode the game is slower)

======================================

That's it. You can now go buy the game.

So first off I'm going to start by saying even though it might show about an hour or so of playtime it does not mean I have not played this game before. I first came across this game at GameStop and I really hadn't played any games since I was young. But I needed a past time because I was dying of boredom being at home laid up in bed unable to do much. I had severely injured my back and I wasn't going to work anytime soon and the depression started to kick in. So anyways by now the game had been out for about 3 years and it looked interesting so I bought it. Went home and started playing it and it was my first time playing a strategy game so I didn't even know if I was going to like it. I started playing around lunch time by the time I know it was dinner time so took 10 minutes got my food and came back and ate while I played. By the time I knew it was freaking 6am the next day! I had never had lost track of time by that much, but man was I enjoying the game. I thought the graphics were pretty decent, the game play was very good and the UI was also good. Of course it was the first time I've had played a game with an in game Civilopedia and I thought that was awesome. The other thing I miss from Civilization III that has not been added to any other Civilization since is building your capital building when your citizens were happy you were able to add one section at a time until you finished upgrading your building. I thought that was fun, even though it was a very simple and quick thing. By the time Civilization IV came out I had around 3500 hours invested in this game and I still have the original disk I bought, but I went ahead and bought it on Steam because they had a very good deal on Civ III, IV and Colonization which I already have the other two also. But I want to keep those disks from getting any damage and besides Steam keeps a running track of your gaming time. So I can safely say this game is what got me back into gaming and becoming a full time gamer. I DO RECOMMEND THIS GAME, EVEN THOUGH IT'S AN OLDER GAME. Keep gaming.

All right. I got this game from a friend sometime around 2012, I think. I played it for a bit but honestly, I had trouble getting into it. A lot had changed from Civilization II and I never really caught on to all the differences.

Picked it up during the Steam Black Friday sale on Thanksgiving. I gave it a whirl. At first, I had the same feelings I did last time I played all those years ago. It wasn't CivII, and the strategies that worked for me then were failing me now. It didn't help that there wasn't a tutorial or a manual of any kind, and the Civilopedia is not the most user-friendly interface, although it's critical to understanding all of the game mechanics the AI employs.

I played on Chieftain for a while, just trying to get a handle on the game mechanics, but now I'm bored of chieftain. Too easy. Once you learn and begin to understand the game mechanics, this is a pretty great game. That said, it's virtually impossible to win if you don't constantly expand and build one city after another. I mean, that is all you will do. Build and build and build. If you don't, the AI will and you'll lose. Pretty much the only way to win is to begin building a ton of cities in the early parts of the game.

I did like the implementation of cultural borders, and how borders clash against one another. The cultural conversion tool was also pretty cool, where cities could rebel and join your forces because they realized that their own culture was lifeless. So it's a pretty good game, and definitely worth the price for my 46 hours (and growing).

I do have to say, though, that a couple of the leader choices are really dumb. Mahatma Gandhi was not a leader of the Indian nation. Although he championed the move for India's independence, making him the face of India is weird, because he was a guru and not a general. And Jeanne d'Arc leading the French? She was a teenager and a peasant who, by her own confession, never even used her sword in combat. They could have chosen Charlemagne or Napoleon Bonaparte, but Joan! Kinda silly!

Still as good of a game as I remember it from my childhood, it's age shows a little, but for $5 (and potentially even less) it still provides that "one more turn" mentality. Having played Civ 5, I have to say that the portraits of the rulers convey far more emotion, at least in my eyes, than the full set pieces of Civ 5. The barbarians have multiple AI options and can be absolutly brutal. Certain civilzations have certain traits which affect what actions trigger golden ages. You get to upgrade your palace in a way that actually changes the way it looks on the city screen. Also there is a city screen where you get a detailed overview of your city and all the wonders you built. As opposed to Civ 5's jam packed 3D model of your city.

Age helps, in a way, since with todays operating systems the turns are lightning fast, even with troop movement.

I know I have my nostagia blinders on, but I really like this game, despite whatever flaws I cannot see. I suspect that anyone who likes these kinds of games and doesn't mind the lack of 4k graphics, will definitely get their money's worth.

Civilization III is one of my long-time favorites. It's fairly complex, very interesting, (from a historical standpoint). The graphics still look quite appealing, even after 15 years. 

The only advancements I've noticed in modern Civ games include, religion, more complex foreign policy, and better AI. I should also mention multiplayer, as the multiplayer aspect of this game died with Game Spy, unless you were to organize a game with friends.

This is still a great game that I would reccomend to fans of the Strategy genre of games, and, I know this is being overused of recent, but I believe, this is truly a game that stands the test of time.

Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization III is a 4x strategy game, that means the objective of the game is to eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate to win. First off, the game takes some time to get the hang of the concept, but it also just takes time to play. A game could last anywhere from 30 minutes to multiple years. I first read the manual for the game which did help out. It told me of keyboard shortcuts that I never actually used. It also explained to me the basics of the game so when I started my new game I wasn‚Äôt completely lost. (This is coming from somebody who hasn't played any strategy games.) The first 30 minutes of my first game I wasted my turns walking around then finally building a city. I played as the Iroquois, they are proficient in agriculture, though I started producing warriors and getting very aggressive. My neighbors killed me and within an hour my first game was over. My second game ended much quicker, within 30 minutes my tiny city was captured. I felt very lost within the first turns of my first game. I felt the game didn‚Äôt do a very good job explaining what to do. I just felt a desire to discover the dark parts of the map because it didn‚Äôt look very good to me. However, I did find the advisors that would pop up and tell me information that I found very useful and helpful. In this way the game was able to help me assimilate myself with it‚Äôs complicated mechanics. 
One interesting mechanic in the 4x strategy game is its robust diplomacy system. There are many treaties, alliances, trade opportunities, agreements to be made, and wars to be waged. On my current playthrough I am a militaristic expansionist Roman empire I encountered the Aztecs and began fighting a war with them.  Upon seeing the I could overthrow them the Aztecs asked for a peace treaty which I agreed to. From there on out the Aztec and I created a rite of passage where we would be able to cross each other's land. However, I plan on expanding cities and surrounding them then I will take over their cities and kill them. This diplomacy system is a major part of my strategy to win the game. This will play a consequential role of my playthrough of this game. 
In general I have never been a big fan of strategy games, however I did find myself enjoying this game to a certain extent. I don‚Äôt expect to be putting too much time into the game anymore, but I can say that my time spent with it has not been all negative.

If you're looking for ludicrous and war-mongering AI, as well as the ability to make your civilization happy without a circus and other buildings that provide happiness, this is the game for you!

In all seriousness, this is a great game. It is 100% worth the $1.24 you pay when it goes on sale! It is very easy to manage your cities' happiness and production! With Civ III, you can que production items, unlike Civ V, which makes the game enjoyable. As well as allows you to have very productive cities. The way it makes that aspect of the game more enjoyable is that you don't have to click on the choose production icon every few turns. However, it sometimes likes to just switch to needless outdated military units after it runs out of production items in a que. Another nice feature of this game is the selecting how you want your game to be set up. It allows you to choose how old the earth is when you start the game. As well as has a few more features that are absent in Civ 5.

The only cons to this are the aforementioned AI, and playing it on a newer computer. The AI are typically kind of crazy when it comes to deals, and get really annoyed if you decline them. Which typically leads to war with them eventually. I seem to have a problem where the AI all declare war with me. Also, the AI expand their civilizations really fast, so if you buy this, make sure to settle as many cities as possible in the beginning of the game! Although that really applies to any Civ Game. Finally, Civ 3 seems to run too fast on newer computers, and it will skip through some animations. 

Other than that, this is a really great game! Especially when it is slightly more expensive than a pack of gum!

The combat feels too random and the AI seems to be overly aggressive (Something is wrong when someone like Gandhi demands tribute and refusing makes them declare war on you.) The AI also is very expansionist, creating new cities whenever it can.

I found no tutorial, so I had to learn how to play the game myself through trial and error.

On the bright side, it comes with its own scenario editor.

Personally this is my favorite turn based strategy. The game is playable for anybody and is very addicting if a person likes to be in control of things. What I like the most, is ability to grow really big, to name stuff as one wants and to play on real World maps. Editor is really simple btw. AI is kind of not really good, but it's challenging on high levels due to bonuses to AI. Also, there is a city count limit on a map which is 512 I think and the game has kind of built in minimal turn waiting time. I have tested this with some members on the community, and it seems that game code doesn't allow for faster operation, regardless of PC hardware one is using. No matter what CPU/RAM/GPU one has, two very powerful cores or 8 core CPU (since the game utilizes only one core by default), the speed of the slowest turn will be the same. Which is considerable, when you have full map of civs, dip relations and modern units.
