Here's what I think of this game, I'll compare it to Civ 5 since most people consider that to be the best Civ game.

Music: Both Civ 5 and Civ III have fantastic soundtracks as with pretty much all Civ games. CIV 5's soundtrack is better, but that doesn't mean this soundtrack isn't worth listening to. 

Diplomacy: The diplomacy here in Civ III, in my opinion is better. You can trade maps technologies, change how agressive the AI is. The AI does get quite a bit agressive once you get to medium agressiveness although.

Scenarios: The scenarios here in Civ III are quite interesting. We have Rise of Rome, Fall of Rome, Napoleanic Europe, WW2 in the pacific, etc. I honestly can't choose between Civ 5 and 3 in terms of which had better scenarios.

War: And here is where we start to see the flaws of Civ III. There are certain units made for attacking, defending, and seige units. The seige units must be protected otherwise they will be either captured or destroyed immediately, and the attacking units are vulnerable to counterattack. Defending units ensure your cities are protected and your attacking armies. This part of war, I liked, It made sure I don't just build completely one type of unit. 
Cities are instantly captured if there is no unit inside. I wasn't as fond of this as the unit diversity, but it was tolerable at least.
But then their's the battle system. It's luck based, which I have a burning hatred for. I could attack a spearman one time with an archer and not take any damage, while another time, a defending spearmen exactly the same as the other one could take out my archer, without taking any damage. How does that make any sense? I get it it's an old game an all, but come on.
Also the AI seem way too powerful. I met Scandinavia on turn 2 and it already said his forces outnumbered mine.

CIv 5 definetly, has better war mechanics.

Barbarian encampment and ruins/friendly encampments: Whether you love 'em or hat 'em these guys are around, some encampment are friendly and will give you something like gold or a settler to give you a huge early game boost. and of course the hostile. You can make the hostile encampments non existant, sedentary, normal, roaming or raging. Since there is more option than Civ 5, I'd say these are slightly better.

Civilization balance: Civilization 5 isn't exactly balanced, (Babylon is much better, is pretty much better every aspect compared to let's say the Iroqouis). Civ's are more balanced here. Each Civ have a unique unit, 2 free technologies and 2 bonus'. Military bonus' allow you to build stronger armies faster, science allows you to build science buildings faster, religious allows you to build cultural building faster, etc. In my opinion the two best are science and religious (Which Babylon ironically has both XD). Besides that Civ's are quite balanced besides early game Unique units (I'm looking at you bowmen)

Victory types: Time victory is always on here, which I don't like (although you can push back the counter for time victory to kick in) cultural victoy revolves around how much culture you can get in either one city or your entire empire, dominatuion requires you to own at certain percentage of the world's population or land area, conquest is to eliminate all rival civilizations., wonder is to build a certain amount of wonders, diplomatic is to get people to vote for you once the UN is built, and space race to leave this filthy planet. All good, although most of the time you will win by either cultural or time.

Graphic: I don't really care for graphics much, but the graphic here are at best, pleasing to the eye and at worst, tolerable.

Conclusion: CIV 5 is obviously better, but Civ 3 is extremely enjoyable also, I have many hours into this, and many more will be put into playing this. I know the flaws I listed here aren't going to be changed unless everyone at Firaxis gets high. I haven't seen any bugs, just a great game.

And now it's time. Your tanks are ready to move on the helpless city guarded only by a few men with spears.

But there is a problem. For some reason, your tanks lose. So you send in the the airforce to soften things up. But, again, men with spears win the day. So, you park a battleship off the coast and start shelling. No damage. No damage.

Wait, an enemy trireme rows up armed with arrows... and sinks your battleship.

That's when you realize. The game is a cheating piece of shit.

The series ended here, as far as I'm concerned. Now, Civ 4 was a good game, and while the less that is said about Civ 5 the better (if you ask me), in my mind Civ 3 was the epitome of the Sid Meier vision for the series and the greatest achievement of aesthetics, style, pacing and general gameplay - as far as Civ gameplay could go.

I think this has a lot to do with the predecessors. Civilization: Call to Power was an epic computer game, surpassing and extremely entertaining. Alpha Centauri was of course one of the very greatest titles the genre has ever seen, encorporating gameplay additions and features - so much recorded voice acting~ - that still feel fresh and ingenious to this day. It was into this setting of established 2D, top down turn based strategy excellence that Civ 3 had to plonk, and what a plonk it was.

How did it work so well? Well it was the way the game juxtaposed itself against it's lineage as much as the way it reproduced and refined it that really rung true with me. Civilzation 3 was all about resolution, refinement, aesthetics and staid excellence. The pacific colours, the fantastic drawn visions of your cities, the subtly faux-3D border markers, the movements of the characters, sounds and the pacing of the game were all just totally lovely touches that made this experience feel high quality and timeless.

Playing it today reveals a game that is completely succesful as a final installment in a series, even though the series itself continued on into the age of 3D. There are flaws of course - in end game especially the dominated maps completely cede any kind of influence over gameplay to your railways, aircraft and ICBMs, the voice acting of Alpha Centauri would have been really great here (it was used for Civ 4, famously, with Leonard Nimoy granting that game degrees of cultural magic that few computer games enjoy) and one could say that consequently the gameplay gets a bit stale towards the later stages of a long game, but it is what happens in the interim - especially the first three quarters of the span of civilization you navigate - that is a really wonderful experience, worth any price.

Play it!

My Dad thinks that games are a waste of time and that one can have much more fun and growth from reading Thackery or Trollope. That being said, he must have put in several thousand hours into this game since he bought it for me around my 6th-odd birthday in 2001. Our primay form of bonding is talking Civ strategy. 

He has no interest in 4, 5, BE or anything like that. Says they're not interesting like this one is. I'm inclined to agree. I think that Civ 3 is the essence of 4X, and that any designer wanting to know what makes 4x games great,  should play this obsessively. There are a few things here and there that I think could have been expanded on- such as plague- and the fact that some civilizations simply have uninspired Unique Units with bland mechanics. Nevertheless, one of my favourite games ever. Now that Civ 6 is happening, I do hope that Meier et al look back to this one, for inspiration, on how a truly grand 4X should be.

Civ 3 Complete on sale for $1.24 so I buy it since I recall how great it was years ago.  I am a big fan of Civ 4 & Civ 5 with all the expansions.  And I am delaying getting a new PC until I know the system requirements for Civ 6.  Still I realize that there was a lot I missed from Civ 3:  Artillery that doesn't suffer damage.  The people's portraits in the city display (I liked Civ I's  full figurines even better).  The fashion progression for world leaders and the population.  (Nineteenth Century attire looks good on everybody; I don't know why).  Single figure unit graphics.  And extremely good graphics for the system requirements.
     And the world is massive.  Civ 5, by giving every unit at least 2mp, really shrank the world.  
     Units simply gain more hits points on promotion; no decision on how to specialize.
     Music that expresses the time frame of the turn.  Civ 5's music is just as varied but seems 
     designed as background music.
Of course it all depends on what one wants from a Civ game.  But if it goes on sale again for $1.24 that's not much of a gamble.

Absolutely amazing game. I've played all linear [i]Civilization[/i] games save for Civ 2 and this has by far been my favourite. I really wish they didn't stray from the feel of the first 3 Civ games, I'm really not a fan of the feel of Civ 5, but alas the masses seem to disagree with me. 

I don't want the bland interface of the fourth and fifth games, I want character, and my loyal advisors to guide me.

I don't want to set my political civic 'Police State' and my economic civic to 'Central Planning'; I don't want to take whatever 'social policy' tree (with permanent effects + no drawbacks) or adopt the 'Order' ideology.
I want to use the 'Communism' government and have my advisors refer to me as 'Comrade' as I free to the proletariat of the world from the bourgeosie and the 'Fascist' Aztecs!

The character of the game, the way events and history play out, managing your empire and waging war, etc. is simply really something and it really seems to have been lost with the new Civ games. And the sad thing is, it has so much potential for future games with more fleshed-out content, features, etc.

When I was a child, I played this on and off constantly and never figuring out what I was doing. I played Diablo 2 around the same time and also didn't know what I was doing. 

This complicated empire micromanaging game is an old classic that many people remember, be it from watching one of your relatives playing or being that relative playing. You must manage large armies and cities while trying to expand your kingdom across the world. Disease, famine, civil unrest and poverty are just some of the factors you will have to deal with with trying to be the greatest empire. Doing things all the time is what will get you ahead, and failing over and over learning what does and doesn't work is the tutorial. Hardcore RTS is defined by the Civilization franchise.

I never really understood this game and I still don't. I never really enjoyed micromanage games as they posed too much stress for me to correctly enjoy them. This is personal and won't sway the game itself. 

This game is for people who love watching massive amounts of action going on at the same time with rediculous difficulty options and really good customization for world generation. For being this old, it holds its complication and difficulty really well. If you love this kind of stuff, then it's a no brainer and if you have never heard of this or just faintly remember it from long ago, make sure you Youtube some videos to make sure its your type of game.

It's not my kinda game, but it might be yours.

There pretty much isn't a bad game in this strategy franchise. The concept is simple: Pick your civ, play through history, win... But the execution is VERY complex. You win in different ways depending on which country you are and which does what. If you try to dominate the world as a civ that specializes in researching technology, Well you're gonna have a bad time. You could be doing amazing for a few hours and a few hundred turns into the game, but make one bad decision or one bad move and you could cripple your empire. This game has hours among hours of replayability and content, and it's relatively cheap. If you get it on sale it's dirt cheap. And I personaly think this Civ is a little easier to pick up and learn then Civ 5, but maybe not everyone will agree with me. But this is a true gem in the strategy genre. Easily a must own for any fan. 9/10.

So many many many years ago I played the first CIV game. I loved it. Barely understood it as I was too young but I loved it. Lost the game at some point and didn't play the other CIV games until I bought CIV4 during a Steam sale. While the graphics improved a lot from the first game I did not enjoy the game as much. It was rather simple and straight forward. So now during another sale I decided to buy CIV3 as a lot of people are saying it's the  best version. A few hours in and I have to say I like this one better then 4. The game is a bit more challenging even on easy mode and I am just having a fun time creating my own civilizations. That however doesn't mean there aren't any downsides. Some things do not make sense like older units being stronger then newer units. Then there is the little glitch that you will constantly be aware of and that is that it looks like the game is freezing at the end of every turn. It just freezes for a few seconds and then continues but it is a bit of a pain. So far I have no had it shut down on me completely like I am reading in other peoples reviews but who knows it might just happen at some point. Honestly for the money I paid for it I won't complain much. It would have cost me more to get the cd version though I wouldn't have the glitch. My opinion? Totally worth playing and if you don't mind waiting a few seconds at the end of every turn get the steam version. If you do then buy the cd version. Have a lot of fun with it! 

P.S. having the chance to build your own castle is something I missed in CIV 4 glad to see it in CIV 3 :)
best game ever
Awesome
great game

I played several hundred hours of this game before it came to Steam.  Steam wouldn't let me import the old disk copy I had so I bought it again, hence the pathetically low hour count.

That being said, this is my favorite of the Civ games.  Simplistic, basic, and at the roots of all things Civ.  Downright fun and addicting, there is nothing more I can say except that you should buy it.
honestly one of the worst games ive ever played.

8/10 - Old as shit, but still amazing

This game has so much detail and strategy. The graphics have held up as well. You can grab this for a cheap price and play for weeks. So many options and choices.

Worth $15

This is a great turn based, kingdom building type game. You choose your race and etc, after which you start the game and start from the bronze age and work your way up to the space age. Its great for those who love turn games that involve monetary and technology base set ups.

This is the first Civilization game that I have ever played. And I have nothing but pleasant memories about it.

It includes all the basic mechanics that define a Civ game. But it hasn't aged very well. The interface is archaic and it's all 2D (except for leader animations). Not that it matters much for a strategy game, but still. 

Civ4 and Civ5 have much more to offer, so it's probably worth playing Civ3 only for nostalgic value. Although, I miss palace customisation and City View with wonders in the later games. Another cool feature is that the leader appearance and title change with each next era

Anyway, if you can get over occasional crashes, you will still spend hours building your empire, but, as I've said, with newer version on the market, Civ3 is mostly for veterans and those who'd like a more challenging game than Civ5.

My overall rating: 7/10

(-2 for crashes, -1 for not being as good as Civ5)

Oldies but goldies :)

This game is dated, and while it does run on the more modern OS's out there, it isn't well optimized.  I found the game running at a steady 8 frames per second on my old Windows 8 machine.  However, most gamers here use PCs powered by 32 gigs of ram and NVIDIA's latest graphics card which requires the heat of the sun to forge properly, so it might run better on your Windows 7 or 8 computer.

The game itself was a staple in my childhood.  I had many hours of fun with it, even though I sucked at it as a kid.  Now, I can lay out a strategy, and retaliate easily when the enemy declares war.

The game itself has quite a bit going on.  You have to balance your gold economy, which can be a challenge as you progress in scientific research, military power, and additions to your city.  You have to make use of the terrain around you, which itself can be a gamble.  You might get everything you need under one generated map, and then get completely fucked by another generated map.  There is a lot to cover, most of which I'll leave you to see for yourself.

In the end, there's a lot of content, and for its current price, its a great game.  If you like strategy games, then you'll probably love this game.  9/10.

This game will never disappear. 
One of the classics.

It may seem a bit anemic compared to the later installments but I find CivIII is still worth picking up to at least try if you're a Civ fan.

While not deep, this 4x experience is very refined, you really do have to play exactly to your Civ's strengths if you want any hope to succeed in the higher difficulties- there is no real catch all method. People may have complained about bombardment and bombers being Op since they can straight up kill units but I find this adds a lot more tactical complexity to war, especially in the mid Ind. age where it really reflects how much warfare at that time was based around defensive positions.

The campaigns within are straight up the best of any vanilla Civ game, Rise of Rome, the Middle Ages and the Age of Discovery are excellent, and hell the Pacific Theatre almost could've been its own game!

Finally, it may be a personal thing, but I've always preferred the isometic display here to the 3d graphics of 4, 5 and Beyond.

And as a small side note, because of how cheap this game is now it can be an effective litmus test to see if you'll even enjoy Civ games, so there's that.

This is an awesome game! I used to play this a long time ago, but it was still way after its release. Old game that holds up. Multiplayer is nice too.

I always come back to this one. civ 3 has ear pleasing music. grathics nothing to write home about but everything like like what it is surposed to be. the ai can be challening to downright stupid. makes things more interesting. and you'll always get to the point where you say ef it and kill everything. but then one spearman holds off 15 units and then germany wants you to join his war. elizabeth won't trade and romes still 10 techs behind. yea for 3 english pounds you'll have a lifetime of fun. (note it was 3 pounds at the time of this review)

1) is actually a gussied up version of Empire (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classic_Empire)
 2) is not the game that I thought (imagined) I was playing 3) when played strictly to win, the optimal gameplay is not fun and ignores most of the advanced features 4) will only leave you feeling dissapointed when you try the sequals and are dissapointed 5) Is so increadly engaging that you will play for DAYS AT A TIME imagining that it's a much better game than it actually is

Okay. I love this game so much, and I'm glad to have it. My problem with this game is technical. It completely screwed up the graphics on my PC. A good modern port shouldn't have issues. Again, a huge thumbs up for the game.... but I'm still trying to find a way to get my graphics working properly again. This is more than a "readjust the resolution" issue.
By far the best of the Cibilization series of games. Infinate replay possibilities. Map editor allows you to make your own maps and play through them. Not a very good multi-player system though.

Great Civilization Game, mechanics are solid, still doesn't look too bad compared to the newer games, although it does show it's age for being a 2005ish game. Has great in-game scenarios/mods out of the box. Only thing I recommend when you launch the game is adding KeepRes=1 in the conquest.ini file as there is no resolution option in-game. Still has multiplayer too. Probably my favorite Civ game with Civ 5 being a close second.
hi all is good game low cost but not have menu no have exit no options is good game
This is one of my favorite games it plays a lot like an RTS

An old one, I can see why it was well liked when it first came out. Not so aged that it is horrible now, but cheap and worth the price. I decided to first try out the series with this one recently and I enjoyed the game. Enough that I am looking to play 4 in the near future.

The army movement and combat isn't deep, but there is enough that you need to be sure where you want the armies to go and make sure you have enough strength at the places you need them. Otherwise you can lose land to an invasion you weren't prepared for. Tech trees are nice, lots of tech through the different ages, some of which reward being the first to research it. Bought this originally when PC games came out in those big square boxes, and to be fair it does show its age. The graphics aren't enivable at all because, well, it is nearly 14 years old. It crashes sometimes too. There is quite a learning curve, but after a while you do get through it. The AI is random or too predictable at times, if they plop a stack randomly into your territory and refuse to leave, they're 90% going to declare war. Playing on easier levels, outsmarting the AI is fairly formulaic, aggressive expansion for the first half, strategically stealing all resources and then ploughing through them all. Small maps are too small, and if you create a massive map (which you can do in the editor, which itself has a learning curve) there is a city limit of 450. The game reaches its limit, but by that point each turn is so long, why bother. Naval conflict is always a bit piddly too. 

But really the base game has a simple enough format that its almost like a PC version of Monopoly. You can play it again and again, no fancy 3D experience or anything, the graphics really don't impede gameplay. 14 years later its still perfectly playable and, importantly, provides a fun and varied experience. Each game comes out wildly different from the last one, and every time you play a new challenge will arise. The randomized earths created offer nearly infinite variety and eliminate any boredom you could experience with similar games. I can easily play this game for hours and hours. Similar to Paradox games, once you start a campaign its hard to finish, there is enough variety in maps you always want to do something else. Games can easily go far into the future, and with some mods you can add some variety onto the existing game's timeline.

Building on the classic Civilization II, Civ III introduces several new game mechanics including expanding City borders & also for the first time animated units. The player starts off in the year 4000 BC with a small group of settlers and some basic knowledge of road building, irrigation & farming. After choosing the site of their first City the player then has to explore and expand their empire to other locations. The ideal placement of a City would be close to natural resources & luxuries, this will help increase trade, production & happiness of the citizens. Connecting City's via roads also increases trade and the sharing of resources / luxuries across your empire. During the early game roaming Barbarians may cause problems along your borders and any unprotected units or land will be either captured or pillaged. As you progress through the centuries you will eventually meet other Civilizations. Some of these will be friendly and willing to trade, others more hostile and may attack you completely unprovoked. You have the opportunity to influence the opinions of other empires by your actions towards them, giving them gifts or trading technology is usually a way to get on their good side. Later in the game you can also forge an alliance with certain empires in the form of a mutual protection pact. This is especially useful during times of War to help seal victory over your enemies. The game ends in one of six ways, the most traditional being conquest (destroying all opponents). The Space race victory occurs when any Civilization completes and launches a Space Ship to Alpha Centauri. Other victory types are Cultural, Diplomatic & Domination. If the game ends and no one is victorious by any of these, the game uses a "histograph" to determine the winner by points.

This is one of my all time favourite games, though Civ IV has more depth by adding religion, unit promotions and other special abilities. I still prefer this version to any other.

There are no in game options for changing to widescreen resolutions but if you do the following: goto your Steam/SteamApps/Common/Sid Meier's Civilization III Complete/Conquests folder then find the file called conquests.ini. Right click to edit the file then goto the bottom and add the line Keepres=1 this will force the game to your monitors resolution.

From the very beginning, every mainline edition of the Civilization series has gotten an average of a 90-95% user approval rate which is a greater approval rate than that normally ascribed to civilization itself. This could be due to the fact that the Civilization seies simply soars while civilization itself seems to soar and stink in equal measure. Then again, it could be that the game of Civilization simply appeals to the inner narcissist lurking somewhere within us all. After all, how often is it you can be elected ruler of your nation by popular acclaim, rule them in a governmental form of your choice, eventually rise to rule to world, establish Earth's first off world colony, and live for centuries. I have to admit that is slightly more ambitious than my own real world expectations, but I do have an eye on the North American continent. Consider yourself warned.

Now don't get me wrong here. I am not trying to say that Civilization is the best turn based, civ building, strategy game ever. That would be unfair to all those games I have not gotten around to trying. What I can say is that it is by far the best I have ever played, and narcissist that I am, I will try most anything that gives me a shot at world domination.

The Civilization series is up to Civ-5 at this point, but Civ-3 is a game which endures the times, remains comparable to like games of more recent production, and holds a special place in my heart when compared to the newer versions of this long running classic. Later editions of this game introduce elements which alter the play style and base strategy of the game, but while I believe that Civ-4 & 5 remain true to the original construct to a large degree, it is Civ-3 which most closely  resembles the original. In fact, it is exactly like the original, but with greater user options, and smoother game play. 

If you have been thinking about giving this series a try, Civ-3 is a great place to start. With the release of Civ-5, the Steam price for Civ-3 is a mere $5.00 which in my opinion makes it one of the best bargains in the entire Steam Library. Just one run through of this game will keep you occupied for longer than the run time of a long movie, and when was the last time you got into a movie theatre for &5.00 eh? I began playing this game when it first came out for PC in the 90's, continue to play it to this day, and played Civ-1 & 2 before that. How's that for a testament for long term replayability? I simply could not recommend another game of this type more highly.

This game has, by far, taken more of time than any other.  In fact I am on my fourth, hopefully final, copy of it.  I orignally was gifted a 3 part CD version of the game from a neighbor who never was into computer games and did not want it.  I played CIV3 nonstop, I would sit in class fantasizing about the game, I would go to sleep dreaming about the game and I still to this day reminisce about specific games I had played close to ten years ago.  I was so hooked that my father took the discs and snapped them in half.  Months of stellar behavior later I managed to earn another copy on my birthday, which was quickly destroyed a month later due to an average of ten hours a day, and 16 hours on the weekend.  I was able to get another disc copy without my parents knowing but I could not control my addiction, causing them to find out about my new copy and promptly destorying it.  Now, able to do things on my own, I bought my latest version on steam for no other reason that I do not feel complete without knowing I have it.  Honestly, this game does not play as well as CIV5 but if you are looking for a changeup, buy it.

General - 8.0
Sid Meier's Civilization is one of the greatest game franchises ever, it's a landmark for every turn-based strategy game. The name itself tells what the game is about, you pick one civilization, select a location to start, select CPU controlled civilizations and settings for that specific map. Your job is to make your civilization meet any of the victory conditions, which can be through science, military, culture, diplomacy, points, etc. The first game of the series I played was Civ II, back in 2001, which instantly made me a fan since then. However I skipped Civ III at its time, and that is what made me buy it many years later. I paid around 1USD for the game just to see what I missed, and unfortunately, not much. Don't get me wrong, it's a great game, but if you played Civ IV, in my opinion, there is nothing in Civ III that will be better than in the later game. It's only worth playing for saudosism purposes. It's heavily outdated.

Content - 8.5
Steam version is a complete version, which includes both expansion packs released. You have a vast number of civilizations to pick and you can adjust some major settings for a location, like temperature, umidity, geological era, water level, etc. You can also chose the victory conditions for a game, which you can fit into your play style, along with difficulty level. The Civilopedia is a tool of great educational value, it contains real data about the civilizations, technologies, unities and almost everything you can find in the game. There is a highest scores table too, but I believe it only displays single-player scores. I don't know if steam is providing some sort of multiplayer support at this time.

Gameplay - 4.0
Like most Civ games, you start with a settler, a worker and/or a warrior in most cases, from this you have to build your city and administer it's growth with the resources gathered around it, which can be selected in the city radius. Each unity you create in a city has a better use, and through the years (turns), as long as your cities and citizens are productive you'll eventually discover technologies which improve your unities and your cities buildings. You can focus your whole civilization in a few aspects or diversify your knowledge. Every civilization on the map have it's own personality and choices, from warmongers to pacifists. What you have to do is to secure your civilization a place in history. But why I give 4.0? It won't help you get started at all. I'm not asking for a strategy guide, I just wanna learn the basics of the game, what's unique to it, what options I have and what they do. I couldn't find a tutorial or at least a checkbox to display tooltips, even the options in the main menu don't have a basic description. It's one of the less intuitive game I've ever seen, unlike it's predecessor ou sucessor. Of course after sometime you'll start to get used to the controls, but they still feel weird. The UI is not friendly even for games older than it is, Age of Empires II is older and has a much more friendly interface and controls.

Graphics - 2.5
The game looks very bad even for its generation, Age of Wonders and Medieval Total War had much better visual quality. Civilization III looks so bad that if affects gameplay, you need to often take a closer look to identify some terrains and unities. There are no options for good graphic enhancements, you can not adjust resolution, it's based on desktop resolution, and even tweaking can't get satisfactory results. I know it's an old game, but the ones I cited are old too and are from the same genre. At least the game showed an improvement compared to the previous title, texture quality is better and there are movement animations for the unities.

Overall - 5.8

Kingston HyperX DDR3 8gb at 1600mhz (x2)
HP 1TB SATA III 7200rpm

Are you looking for a Time sink?

Here you are!

This is a basic turned based Real Time Strategy game based around building a civilation from a tribal state to a modern age.

The Charm of this game really comes from your opponates, how they'll mock you, or try to threaten you to give them what they want. You can completely civil, or you can be a thorn in everyone's side, which can get to the point of the entire planet trying to destroy you.

A problem is that the mechanics can be confusing, heck it took me a solid three hours of reading to get a basic grasp on the game. but once you learn it, it's down, and it become second nature.

Another problem, if you can call it one, is that this game will burn hours of your life without your consent, seriously, you will play 4 hours stright and swear it was maybe 30 minutes.

8/10 
PROS:
Great RTS game play
Aged nicely
great freedom to choose

CONS:
Quite a few things to learn to even start playing
Will sink hours without you knowing it.
Playing this game for more than 8 years. Absolutely BEST strategy game ever.

The franchise is run through to the bitter end, with players opting for piracy and spacecraft without help or hail-mary, as the plot devolves unerringly to next advances in technology. The tech tree from Civilization II carried the throne room. In Civ III, the multiplayer and marginalised are in an open door to cultural centres around the world, egging on the tech-savvy, New York hipster, python coding sky rise. The introduction is the selling point. Closing on the propogandist last installment, Civilization V: Brave New World. Not everyone knows, but Huxley's Brave New World Revisited is a non-fiction debacle couched in a comfortable sequel for bugs from early adolescence to young adulthood. The gateway to television since Iraq is clouded by war still now, and today, a friendly reminder of our spiritual needs as anthropogists is as healthy as any Black Sabbath. Drugs tear families apart. But babies need drugs to grow. Weather control is a superpower. I recommend frequent save games with a friend

Dont trust the one line fanboy reviews. This entire series is one those emperors new clothes type of games. No one wants to say how crap it really is because its a 'classic'. 

There is no strategy involved. It really doesnt matter what you do. You wait for your advisor to tell you what to build and you click ok. The game is very buggy. A strange glitch produces seven of your main characters eg 7 Queen elizabeths. It randomly crashes when attacking a city. 

The 'city view' has to be the single most pointless thing I have seen in any game. An identical view for each city that is of no use whatsoever. 

The cartoonish attempt at humour is just embarrasing and ruins the feel of the more serious stuff like the scientific research, that would have been interesting if it was more detailed. The AI are not funny or clever for that matter. 

If you like strategy and history this will not challenge you in any way, maybe get it for your kid?

My first real video game, being brought up on all those educational "Leap Start" games from way back when, never getting any real games until this one, I loved it from the very first turn. This game is quite possibly one of the best strategy games ever created. It has perfect balance, great gameplay, its very hard to win but you still have fun with it because of the flawless design, the units are all unique and each one is cool in its own way, from the days of stones and swords to fighter jets and skyscrapers, you'll have fun forever. I still remember my first victory, so many years later. I remember just how proud I was, looking at all those beat up other leaders, mine staring at them with a shit faced grin of complete pompus superiority, I felt like I was god. When you actually win, which I've only done once, it feels SO FUCKING GOOD. You feel like you just took over the world in real life, especially with all the other leaders sitting there, cowering before your might! Its just awesome, please please buy this game, it is a classic that will never die, and everyone should get it, try it at least once. 9001/10

This is my favorite civ game by far. Civ V is great and all, but my biggest complaint about it is that you can only have like 20 nukes tops. Civ III lets you have as many as you so desire. Plus, you get ICBMs (as many as you want)! Civ V doesn't let you have ICBMs. However, in Civ III, I've got ICBMs in at least 20-30 cities, tactical nukes everywhere, subs (with tacticals) spread all across the map targeting all coastal and inner coastal cities. I can start WWIII any time I want, and I can be sure that I will have no shortage of nukes. Plus just painting some island in that b, e, a, utiful orange coat is just a pleasure. Get Civ III, don't waiste your money on Civ V.
i loved this game when it came out and i love it now

The game is old. The game is definetly recomented from my part.

I had to lower the screen resolution to avoid the 'tiny-litle-units' making my ayes go into pain. :-) But after all these years, I really enjoyed again the struggle to build a sivilization. There are newer versions of the same game nowdays. But I really believe that each of the Civilization games has its unique satisfaction to offer the strategy gamer, even if Civ IV is my prefered one.

I definetly recoment CIV III, especially moded with mods like "Rise And Rule", which add many new units, technologies etc.  The problem is, I can not clearly identify what is this 'different gameplay aspects' that kept me playing CIV II all these hous and not starting a CIV IV or CIV V campain... The differenses on units, wonders, railway inprovements etc, should not be enouph to get me playing a game as old as this one... On the other hand, I got myself missing the real-movie councelors of CIV-II, but I don't think I will play that old love again :-)

In any case. Considering the very low price that you can purchse this old game (Civilization III), especially in a bountle together with the newet versions, I definetly believe that any gamer that likes turn -base build-expand strategies should give it a try. Even for the shenarios of the 'complete' edition, a CIV-V fun could find in CIV-III a way to further expand his Civilization gamepleasure.

Have a good game everyone :-)

My friend introduced me to this game a long time ago, and I can't thank him enough! although I only have 2 hours on the steam version I happily spent hundreds ( at least) on the disc version he loaned me ( back when you could do that). 
   But anyway the reason your reading this is to learn weather or not this game is worth 5 bucks to buy. To answer that you must ask  yourself some questions.
1) do you like running your own country and mercilessly clicking other countries to death?
2) do you like exploring randomly generated worlds and clicking other countries to death?
3) do you like sending hundreds of units at enemys to make them fight to the death with other countries units by clicking?
4) do you enjoy classical music while clicking other countires to death?
5) do you care that there are 3 newer versions of the game?

If you answered yes to 1-4 and no to 5 BUY THE GAME
If you answered yes to 5 don't buy the game you nostalgia hater
If you answered no to 5 and yes to 3 of the first 4 questions then BUY THE GAME
If you answered no to 5 and yes to 2 of the first 4 questions you may want to consider waiting untill the game goes on sale
If you answered no to 5 and yes to 1 of the first 4 questions you may be looking at the wrong genre of games 
If you answered yest to 5 and no to the first 4 questions you ARE looking at the wrong genre of games

Civilization III (or Civ III for short) is an argricultural war simulator, in which you build wheat, farm iron, and thresh people in a significant battle over land and cities.


Should you take too long to murder your foes, the game may decide to just let you win by saying you're so cultural that there's no way they can challenge you, and they automatically forefeit. Which is stupid, because a rich culture like that is not as likely to have the vast killing potential an uncultured brutish army nation would, but alas, not everything in life, or Civ, is logical.

I purchased this game in order to understand and have an enlightenment on the essential game mechanics of the Civilization game series. I am still not sure whether Civilization III was the right choice.

Here are a few topics that I wish to highlight:
- It is a low-paced, turn-based strategy game with a significant amount of historical content.
- There are a few variables in the game that the person should learn before starting to play. Luckily, steam provides us with a manual, so DO read it.
- For beginners, this game may become tough, even at the lowest difficulty setting. Even after learning the basics, there are many things one can do wrong.
- This game can take MANY hours of your time, and once your civilization has more than 10 settlements, it may take more than a minute to play each game turn. In addition, there may be dozens and dozens of turns before a victory condition is met.
- Although it DOES seem to work on my Windows 8.1 machine, there are a few frustrating issues, such as window switching not restoring the original resolution until the game is terminated. Also, the game may occasionally crash on some particular user, and so far it has always crashed after the end of a game. This means that the game could have had a better preparation for modern systems.

Therefore, it is both hard to recommend and unrecommend this game. Take this as a midline evaluation. If you have time to spare, go ahead and give it a try. Or who knows, the other games in the series might be more interesting.

OKay, First off, this may be a little biased as Civ 3 was the game that introduced me to the franchise. That said, It' s a solid 4X title, Graphically, it's obviously not going to be State of the Art, but I've never found that to matter with this genre; and apparently neither have most people given that one of the most popular 4X games around is Alpha Centari, which came out in 1999. 

Sorry, got a bit off topic.

Like all the Civ games, Civilization 3 puts you in control of a settler and warrior, kicks you into the oceon that is its game play and tells you to swim. The tutorial is there, but it's basically a series of tips that pop up when you start doing things. well written and concise, but they don't force your hand. Also like the other Civ games, there is a large tech tree and ages to advance through as your empire grows. The main appeal of the game is that no two playthroughs [which can take weeks to months if you play casually] are ever going to be the same. One game History may play out as you destroy the Aztecs as the Spanish... but in the next game, Gahndi might nuke your American ass into oblivion. 

Ultimately, 4X games aren't for everyone, but everyone should give the genre a try and at the price they're asking for it, Civ 3 is an affordable, still good looking, and complete introduction to the genre as well as a game that experienced players will enjoy for years to come.

[[A note on the CIv Franchise: those of you who started civ with 4 or 5 should also give 3 a try, the three titles are honestly different enough that they could be said to be equally good in their own right, assuming of course that you have the DLC for Civ 5, otherwise.... *shudders*]]

Let me say that this was my first Civilization game, and for being on sale for $5, I am sure I would buy the game again.

If you're new or interested in Civilization games, I HIGHLY recommend reading further and/or watching videos to understand what you are getting into:

Pros-

This game is highly detailed and allows for a significant amount of strategy-management decisions. Learning the system and "how to beat it" itself was an enjoyable that I still can't fully claim to have achieved.

Cons-

There is no help in-game in actually learning the game. This will either add hours of patience in learning the game, or frustration.

The computer AI is abhorrent for trading.

Fair Warning: This game is SLOW. I am okay about slow games, when I am mentally prepared for it. This game is so slow, whether due to micromanagement, organizing your thoughts, or constant unit/city decisions. In my opinion, the pacing of this game is not evidence of a detailed well thought out game (which yes, it is), but of a poorly designed game. Even in "speed-mode"...just ugh, it's still slow.


I suggest that if you are interested in a strategic, decision-making game, and ok with long games, the Civilization games will suit your needs. Furthermore, I suggest looking into Galactic Civilizations, at the least for the sake of a real tutorial.

Again, if you're new to these games, do your research and check out other people's opinions before diving into the Civilization world.

Many believe this to be the best Civilization game in the series, and I have to agree. No other Civ has the same amount of sheer content as this one: From civs to leaders, buildings, wonders, scenarios, you name it. Also, the leader's personalities shine, and the diplomacy system is much deeper than in the newer iterations, you can basically tell Ghandi to go fuck himself if he pisses you off. In general, the game is deeper than both its successors, but the tutorial does a good job of teaching you the basics. The rest can be learned through experience. The only thing that I feel could turn someone off is the graphics, which look a bit outdated by now, but if you're willing to look past the surface, hours upon hours of fun await.

It's not a bad game, and I can see why some people find it charming, but to me it's an awkward transitional phase between Civilization II and Civilization IV.  I would recommend playing those games instead, and seeing which one you like better.

For a game made all the way back in October 2001, this is a fantastic game.

First off, if you bought Civilization Revolution for the Xbox 360 or iPad, that is nothing compared to this old but fantastic game.
Secondly, make sure you play this when you havn't got anything else to do in the next 24 hours because this game takes some time and patients and you are guranteed to get 100% addicted.
However, if you want to go online, nobody will be on there and if you host a server nobody will join (unless, of course, one of your friends have the game and you invite them). Also, on your first game you ever play, make sure you make it so it's on the easiest difficulty and do a little amount of Civilizations otherwise you will get brutally battered like a Cod fish.

10 features Civilization 3 has that Civilization Revolution Doesn't

1. You can alter the map size between Tiny and Huge.
2. You can alter the settings on how to win the game.
3. The Middle Age is included.
4. You get workers to build Outposts, Mines, Barricades, Irrigation (farm/food resources) etc.
5. There is more research.
6. More units.
7. Create your own map in the editor.
8. Edit the map properties.
9. More Civilizations.
10. More Civilizations allowed to be active in game.

Keep in mind that Civilization Revolution is newer than Civilization 3.
I can't really think of anything you can't do in Civilization 3 that you can in Civilization Revolution.

Well I was hoping for a different experience from Civ IV.  I was hoping that Civ IV was that point where the devs went through a 'lets temporarily sell out and fuck up the franchise for a while' phase, but it turns out Civ III is shitty as well.

Okay, it's not as silly as Civ IV.  In may ways, I still despise Civ IV, but I'll admit it's a nitpick.  I'd give it the same rating otherwise, because it's almost the same game.  Civ IV's interpretation of religion is silly.  Read the other review for more about that.

Okay, enough about fucking Civ IV, lets talk about Civ III.  But what is there to talk about really?  I tried to have fun, but it was the dullest 5 hours on chieftain (easiest difficulty) of moving around a bunch of soldiers and workers (that's all this game is, soldiers and workers and building ROADS) with the scandinavian vikings that I used to conquer the Aztec empire (ultimately a game of city tag), while fending off Japanese and Romans, I've ever had.  Eventually, I resigned, because Sumeria was really big, Persia entered a 'golden age', and I had to end it at some point.

There was no way to end this game properly without playing for another 8 hours, and that was a standard size map.  The one thing I sorta appreciated was how the enemy leaders poke fun at you for quitting.  The victory screen scores, such as 'children per family', 'population', and 'average lifespan', are mostly purely for flair and meaningless.  

Final Score - 38/100

Sorry, CIV I and II fans.  No more Diplomat units.  A very different experience than CIV IV, which became awesome with all the fine mods available.  I admit. This game hits my Turn-Based-Strategy  sweet spot for kicking back and wargaming. Gets my Happy Camper award.

MAJOR IRRITATING PROBLEM:  From the origional, after a unit moves, the game jumps to the next (not nearest) unit that may be half a world away.  There is no way to stop and look at what your just-moved unit saw without scrolling to find it.  This becomes very irritating after a while.  I had forgotten about it.  It is not a bug, it is programming design.  This got fixed in later games so the game paused after each unit moves, allowing you to stay in an area and complete a battle before moving on by hitting a key when YOU are ready.  Think of a scar on Mona Lisa's face.   Think of a good movie that periodically stutters, jumps or freezes.   Oh, wait.  I already have that.  Verison FIOS, may the gods bless their awesome up and download speeds.

Civilization 3 is the third installement in the popular turn-based strategy series and personally my favorite. 

First of all this title still holds up tremendously well nowadays, it runs on newer operation systems and you can tweak the resolution in a file making the game really great to play. There aren't any issues at all.

Civ3 is not as complex as Civ4 and doesn't have such intricate indepth mechanics but still manages to keep the player busy, you have to manage several aspects of your empire. The more streamlined gameplay makes this Civilization my favorite, it's easy to understand but yet very hard to master. You get down the basics really fast but in order to be good at it, you need some serious practise. There are tons of different civilizations to choose from and many different scenarios. The included expansion offer even more content. The AI is really good and easily challenge you, even on lower difficulties.

The third installment in the Civilization series which is getting pretty old these days, with it's successor Civilization IV and V.  This is another one of those titles that you might have grown up with as a kid and have had nostalgic value to you. This is at least the case for me. I remember that the game took a chocking 700 MB of space on my hard disk and it was generally tanking my late 90's computer. I have sunk a huge amount of hours into this game and for me this is the best game in the series.

Civilization is probably the most dominating Turn-based strategy game in the gaming industry. The Total Wars games for example are RTS/TBS hybrids, while CIV is completely TBS. True Civilization enthusiasts probably rank Civ3 pretty low, compared to Civ2, Civ4 and Civ5 which were very well received for their times. For me however, Civilization 3 is the favorite among the ones I've played (Civ3, Civ4 and Civ5). Again - because of it's nostalgic value.

All Civ games start out the same way unless you play a scenario or campaign. You start off with a settler and a warrior of some sorts. The settler can build a city, and as you find a suitable location for your capital - let your Civilization begin! Beware though, once you have started a game you won't be able to leave for at least 4 hours. This game is honestly best played during the night and is mostly a single-player experience.

There is a Campaign/Scenario mode, where you play historical events or just silly settings. As well as a multiplayer mode, but I have never enjoyed these ones at all. Nothing beats that random map mode, select the terrain, the climate, map size and your opponents/allies. Let the history get rewritten as you choose the path of the righteous, or the path of the tyrant. Through exploding expansion, racing technology, crushing warfare and cunning diplomacy you must stand victor as the one and only dominating superpower.

[b]I only recommend picking this up if you have a personal connection to it, or if you are entirely out of gameplay from modern titles.[/b]

[u]Note: You might want to check out [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/8930/]Civilization V[/url] ([url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/mendozacheers/recommended/8930/]Review[/url]) as it's a modern take to the genre and series.[/u]

Sid Meier's Civilization III, the sequel to the great Civilization II, a game that by some is still to this day considered to be the best of the series, has the heavy duty challenge of not only living up to the standards set by it's predecessors but also to innovate the franchise enough that players of the previous installment can be bothered to upgrade.

It starts out with a somewhat mixed feeling. Some of the great ideas from Alpha Centauri has been brought over creating a much more versatile playing field with a living map and more unique factions but many of Alpha Centauri's greatest assets, such as the ability to build your own units and terrain elevations are notably absent. and others, such as unique factions, are only half implemented.

These improvements however do still manage to increase the interactivity of the game substantially particularly when combined with the many new features, such as culture, that Civ III brings to the table.

Factions are not longer defined simply by their city names but now have a few unique units of little consequence and civilization traits of great consequence. Unique units are simply beefed up versions of regular units that give a faction a small military advantage during the time period in which the unit is present, this can be a nice boost if you happen to go to war in that time but it can also be ignored completely if the time for war is not right. The traits each faction receives now however are of a much greater importance and can range from getting a free technology every age to a half off cost on religious buildings. These traits are big enough in effect that they tend to define your entire game.

A new and important feature in Civ III is culture. Each city generates culture through it's various buildings and the culture in turn defines the size of it's borders. A heavily cultured city can even envelop the city of an opponent and flip it to your side. While the realism or historical accuracy of such a device is laughable at best it does provide players with a new means of expansion and a way to deal with those pesky resource stealing late game cities that the AI is so fond of placing in whatever unoccupied corner of your empire it can find.

Graphically Civilization III is passable as always, the city view is pleasant but the rest of the game gives only a mediocre visual experience. Nothing pretty but nothing that'll ruin your gaming experience either. The soundtrack is still mostly orchestral epics and works very well although the rest of the sound effects in the game are pretty forgettable.

All in all Sid Meier's Civilization III is a good sequel. It doesn't create quite the same feeling of amazement and enjoyment that going from Civ I to Civ II does but it manages to provide a good solid experience with enough innovation to justify the purchase.

I didn't give this game a fair try back in the days when it was new.  The game was visually an improvement over Civ II, and the interface was actually functional.  I just felt the combat system was poorly done, diplomacy didn't feel right, and the game has a few design quirks.  Fast forward to now, I decided to buy the complete edition, which updates the game.  What I find now is a game that truly stands between the majesty of Civ II and Civ IV.  The Civ experience is there, and it's well represented.  The graphics haven't aged all that well, and the interface isn't as nice as the later games, but the gameplay remains classic Civ.  The complete edition adds the feature of customizing the game in ways never seen before or again in a Civ game, such as turning down (or up) AI aggression.  It is a good, cheaper entry into the world of Civ.
I couldn't say this is the best Civilization game out there, but with it's low cost, it's definately worth the extra pound/dollar.

The best of the franchise.  I started playing the original shortly after it came out, it blew my mind.  CIV2 made minor enhancements, but was largely the same game.  The first time I played CIV3, I hated it.  The strategies I had developed for 1&2 no longer worked (the catapult is quite different, for example) and it took me a few minutes to grok the culture concept.  Once I did (and learned the unit differences), I never went back.  The AI is sooo much better than before and unlike CIV4 (which despite buying and forcing myself to play, I never enjoyed), you still get to micromanage a great deal (but you can also automate quite a bit - the ability to choose is awesome).  Buy it on sale if new to the franchise & start with a tiny world.  If you are used to another CIV game, don't wait for a sale, buy it now & get to know the differences in the tech tree as well as the unit differences - I bet you'll like it!
